APPLICATION FOR ADMISSION

To the
Director of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada

Sir,

I hereby make application for admission of the undermentioned child into INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL the United Church of Canada Residential School; to remain therein under the guardianship of the Principal for such term as the Minister of Mines and Resources may deem proper:

Indian name of child: BLUE MOUNTAIN GIRL
English name: FRANCES TWO YOUNG MEN
Age: 10
Name of Band: WESLEY
No. of ticket under which child's annuity is paid:
Father's full name and No.: ISAAC TWO YOUNG MEN
Mother's full name and No.: LUCY
Parents living or dead: Living
State of child's health: Good
Religion: U.C. OF C.
Does applicant speak English? No
Previously attended school for years

(Signature of father)

I hereby certify that the above application for admission has been read over and interpreted to the parent or guardian and that the contents were understood by him or her and that I witnessed his or her signature to this document.

Signature of Missionary or other Witness

NOTE—If mother or guardian signs, agent must forward full explanatory note.

I recommend the admission of the above child, who is of good moral character and is eligible to be admitted as a grant-earning pupil.

Agent

*Principal or other official of the school must not sign as witness.

NOTE—All the above particulars must be fully given, especially the "Name of Band," "No. of ticket under which child's annuity is paid" and "Religion." The minimum age for admission is seven (7) years, except in the case of an orphan, destitute or neglected child. When application is made for the admission of such cases, full particulars should accompany the application.

Dear Dr. Murray:

With reference to the Department's request for more information regarding the girl Ruby Snow shown on the last quarterly returns, I beg to advise that this girl as you are aware has been in school since the early part of 1938, but her name has always appeared up until this time on the day school returns.

With the cancelling of the grant for day school, her name was transferred over to the regular Residential School list. We are aware but perhaps this is not clear to you why it was necessary for us in order to obtain the day school grant to show several children who were actually in residence on the day school return, the names of course never appeared on both lists. Now that all our children appear on the blue return the transfer was effected of Ruby Snow from the day school to the Residential School. At the time of her admittance application was made in the regular way and the necessary authority given.

I regret the confusion caused by this procedure but hope that this explanation will clear the matter up.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

I wish to bring to your attention the case of Sam Labelle and Mary Labelle, both children of Thomas Labelle of the Red River Sioux Black, Sioux. These two children were pupils at the Youville Indian Residential School for several years. I am informed that a year ago last September the local Agent took these two children out of the Youville School and entered them at the Morley School. It would seem that this was done without the authority of the parents.

As these children were brought up as Catholics and as their religious affiliation will almost necessarily be changed if they are allowed to remain in the Morley school, Rev. John O'Connell, Superior of the Youville School, would like to know if the Department would be good enough to have these children transferred back to the Youville School.

Anything that the Department may be able to do in this matter will be greatly appreciated.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

J. O. Currie

Dear Father Plourde:

I have your letter of the 7th instant with reference to Sam and Mary Labelle.

I have reviewed the quarterly return of the Youville Residential School and cannot find any pupil by the name of Labelle. There was a pupil named Mary Labelle Pepin, No. 631, who entered Youville School in 1938 and is last shown on the return for the quarter ended September 30, 1939, and marked "Has left the Reserve -- now at Morley Agency". Possibly this is the girl to whom you refer but on checking the September quarter return of the Morley Indian Residential School there is no mention of her having been admitted to that school.

There is no record in the returns of Sam Labelle. Before writing to Morley I should appreciate it if you would let me know if Mary Labelle Pepin is the girl to whom you refer in your letter of the 7th instant.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Father Plourde:

I desire to refer to Sister Ste. Sabine's letter of December 4 which you left with me.

It refers to Clara Labelle who is stated to be a pupil of the Morley Indian Residential School. In your previous letter of November 7, 1940, it is evident that the girl about whom the Sister is writing at one time attended the Youville School.

On the recent return of the Morley School there is shown the name of Clara Labelle, 14 years of age, Shiniqui Band, daughter of Thomas Labelle. As the Shiniqui Band is in the Morley Agency I am doubtful if this is the same girl to whom Sister Sabine refers.

There is also in the Morley School a girl named Caroline Julia Labelle, a member of the Bearspaw Band and a daughter of Alec Labelle.

You might let me know if either of these girls is the one about whom Sister Sabine is writing and at the same time you should request the Sister to state the exact date that the "Clara Labelle" mentioned in her letter attended the Youville School, also her register number at that school. If we had this information we might be able to trace the matter further.

Yours truly,

Rev. J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.,

Sir:

I have your letter, file 119-1-10 dated 14th July 1942 for acknowledgment.

With regard to pupils at the school who are 16 years or over, I discussed this matter at considerable length with the Principal, Mr. E.J. Stanley. He said he would like to hold the matter over and release some of the girls until about the time of the opening of the school term, because he would like to settle about four of these older girls, but at this time he does not know which ones will be available.

Mr. Stanley is experiencing great difficulty in getting sufficient and usable help, chiefly due to the present conditions and labour shortage. The services of some of these older girls will help materially to relieve the situation.

Therefore it might be in order to wait a while before submitting the requested discharge applications when a full detailed report will be submitted for your approval.

Trusting the foregoing explanations are satisfactory to you, and that due consideration be given to the present unavoidable circumstances.

Your obedient servant,

MORLEY, Alberta.
May 14th. 1945.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

With reference to your letter 119-1-10, dated 15th April in connection with the discharge of certain pupils at the Morley Residential School.

On checking my Agency Register I find that some of pupils you mention are not yet 16 years of age, however on my official visit to the School I took the matter up with the Principal he said sometimes the application for admission forms did not show their correct ages as he usually relied upon the Indians to tell him the children's ages, however we have decided the following with regards to the older boys and girls:

061- Rita Rider Born 28th Jan. 1928. To remain in school another year

064- Leta Powderface Died a few days ago. TB.

067- Susan Smalleyes Born 24th Aug. 26. Will be discharged.

068- Elba Lefthand 18 Nov. 28. To remain in school another year.

069- Georgie Daniels 10 July 26. Will be discharged.

096- Winnie Amos 15 July 27. " "

Boys:

74 Walter Chiniquay 10th May 27. Will be discharged.

79 Wallace T.Y.M. 3rd Apr. 27. " "

81 Carl Simeon 13th Feb. 28. " "

88 Dillon Coit 1st Aug. 27. " "

Application for discharge of the foregoing will be requested.

There are 7 school children in the Morley Indian Hospital suffering from TB, it is very probable that they will remain there for an extended period. There were 6 but one died a few days ago, however I am pleased to state that there appears to be considerable improvement in the condition of most of the patients.

I would like to mention that excellent progress has been made at the School in the manual training classes, the older boys are showing wonderful response in the making of various articles (household things), such as Medicine Cabinets etc. but what struck me most were the Kitchen Cabinets of which there were seven all completed, with the exception of 3 which still need the small heading and the glass in the doors.

They are all the same size and style they measure 42 in. by 24 in. x 66 in. high in the lower part. There are 2 cupboards and two drawers and above the table top there is another cupboard with glass doors opening in middle, with hooks for hanging cups and small heading inside near the back to set plates on their edges.
These cabinets are very well made and are attractively painted in various colors, I would estimate them to be worth at least $25.00 each.

The boys are very proud of their work and they will be allowed to take them home at the end of the school year. In my opinion, this type of training should be encouraged. I would suggest that further materials should be furnished for next year's manual training but, I think they should get their supplies during the summer vacation, in order that they may commence immediately in the new school year and also in time to allow the lumber to become properly dried out (most of the lumber purchased nowadays is very green).

I cannot say that the progress in the class room is anything wonderful, the majority of the children are just mediocre but there seems to be a few bright pupils.

The sewing classes are doing very good work, repairing clothes and making over old clothes into various useful garments, this is very good training, there is also a beadwork class one afternoon each week, when the girls are shown how to make leather goods, gloves, mitts, mocassins and the like, with bead trimmings, some of the work is very good both in design and workmanship.

J.N.R. Iredale
Acting Indian Agent.

Ottawa,
March 1, 1944.

Reverend Sir:

On the December quarter return of the Morley Indian Residential School you show the names of pupils 125, Ronald Pousette, and 0131, Margaret Jimmy John. In both cases you requested and were allowed 92 days' grant for these pupils.

In checking the return the Auditor General found that on the admission and discharge sheet which you forwarded with the return you state that pupil Ronald Pousette, No. 125, entered the school in December (but the exact date of that month is not shown) which would mean that you are only entitled to grant for him from the date of admission to December 31, or 92 days.

In the case of pupil 0131, Margaret Jimmy John, you did not state the actual date of her admission on the admission and discharge sheet.

As you are aware, in the case of new pupils you are only entitled to grant in the first quarter in which they enter from the exact date of entrance to the end of that particular quarter.

Please let me know immediately the month and the exact date on which both pupil 125 and pupil 0131 entered the Morley School.

In reviewing your returns I find that under the heading "Date of entrance to school" you have only shown the year in which the pupils entered. In

Rev. E.J. Staley,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Morley, Alta.
future you should follow the practice of other residential schools by stating not only the year but the month and the date in the month. This will permit both the Department and the Auditor General to make certain that you are requesting the correct number of days' grant.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Residential School
United Church of Canada

Ottawa, February 17, 1945.

Dear Mr. Staley:

We have just received your December quarter return and on reviewing it find that you request 92 days' grant for each of the following pupils: Numbers 128, 129, 131 and 0137. On the I.A. 411 form you simply state that the pupils mentioned entered the school in December, 1944. You do not state the exact date in December when they actually entered at any time during the month of December, you are only entitled to grant from the date of entrance to the end of the quarter.

I enclose another copy of circular letter of December 29, 1944, which you have evidently not studied carefully. The information regarding pupils should be the same both on the return and on the I.A.411 form. In addition, you will note the circular letter requires that under the heading "Date of entrance to school" you should show the exact month and day of the entrance of each pupil. As it is possible that you made a mistake on the I.A.411 form and that the pupils actually entered the school on October 1, 1944, whose dates would entitle you to 92 days' grant during the December quarter, I am sending back your return, in order that you may make any corrections necessary so that the information on the return and on the I.A.411 form will be the same.

It is also noted that the names of pupils numbered 074, 075 and 078 are not shown on the December quarter return, although they appeared on the September quarter return and no application has been received in the meantime for their discharge. Either you forgot to include their names on the return - in which case you are entitled to grant for them - or you neglected to include their names on the I.A.411 form showing the exact date on which each of them left the school.

Yours sincerely,

Rev. E.J. Staley,
Indian Residential School,
Morley, Alta.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

As it was believed that Lorraine was at the Stony Sun Dance being held west of Morley patrol was made to that point where her father was attending but stated he had not seen the girl, but thought it possible she might be staying by herself at some of the empty homes in or around Chinko village. Patrol continued around the Reservation until the girl was finally located staying with her grandmother Adeline Soldier. The girl was very reticent about returning back to school but after much persuasion agreed to go back, where she was handed over personally to Rev. E.J. Staley, Principal who reprimanded Lorraine.

Dear Doctor Dorey:

We have just received a report from Mr. J.N.R. Iredale, Acting Indian Agent, Morley, Alberta, concerning a council meeting held October 15, 1946, to discuss school matters in the agency. The report reads as follows:

"I pointed out to the meeting that there were a number of vacancies for pupils at the school and asked them to get the school filled to capacity without any further delay. We still have room for about 20 pupils.

"I explained that I had discussed this important matter with the Inspector, Mr. G. H. Gooderham, and that all Family Allowances for children of school age would be withheld until the Morley Indian Residential School was filled to capacity. That only those who had made application for admission for their children would be placed on the grounds of no available room with the exception of those refused or unable to attend for medical reasons. This statement was in connection with children living in Morley and did not apply to children residing in the Nordegg or Pekisko areas.

"Eddie Hunter read a report regarding education which was submitted by the Alberta Indian Association to the joint committee of the House of Commons and the Senate this spring in which they ask for an addition to the present classrooms of another two rooms for day classes.

"There was quite a discussion by the Indians on this matter.

"Chief Enos Hunter asked 'If a child was attending a day school would the Family Allowance be continued to the parents?' I answered 'Yes'.

Enos Hunter said there were lots of complaints. He said some of the boys who are now in school asked one of the members of the school staff, "How much money am I getting for working half days doing chores at the school?" The answer was "You get nothing. You are working for your clothes."

He continued, "I asked one of the older girl pupils, 'Are you getting proper education?' She answered 'No.' She also said 'We older girls have never been in the class rooms for two years.'

Another pupil told Enos Hunter that she did not like the school because "We get too much games and playing and not enough time in school work."

Alex Baptiste said "I have four children in school and since Mr. Stanley went away the conditions are getting worse." He said the clothing issued to the children is very poor and yesterday he had to buy clothing for two of his children because the clothing they had on was not good enough to keep them warm.

Tom Kaquits said he asked two Indians, Moses Chiniquay and Noah Goat, why they did not have their children in school. Chiniquay said his boy Leonard was at school but during the last two years he was only in the class room once or twice a week and the rest of the time he was doing outside work. He said he got the same reply from Noah Goat.

Tom Simeon says he had one girl age 15 years, who should be in school. Asked "Why is she not in school now?" he replied "She cannot get along with the staff at the school, always trouble and he said they don't get enough class room work and most of the time they have to do work and that is what causes the trouble.

John Bearspaw said he had two girls in school. One was in for eight years. He was satisfied with her. The other was also in school for eight years and when she finished school her education was very poor. He said he asked her why she hadn't
learned more and she replied that the last two years she was in school she never went to the class room but was kept doing chores all the time.

"He continued, I have a boy eight years old but I hesitate to send him to school because I cannot be sure but that when he is old enough he will be made to do chores when he should be doing school work like the white children.

"Then quite a number of Indians started to talk and said they wanted to get a day school. Nearly all the Indians present at the meeting said they favored a day school.

"The chiefs and councillors went on record all stating they wished to see a day school opened as soon as possible which would operate in conjunction with the present residential school.

"David Simon said that all his children had finished school. They all liked to go to school but he did not like residential school. When he was young he went to school for two years and he liked it. He said a little work is alright but not too much. He liked to see children well fed and well clothed.

"John Powderface said he wanted to see all the children get well educated and he would be in favor of anything that would improve conditions. He was 100 per cent in favor of a day school.

"He said that half a day in the school room is no good. Sometimes the parents have to leave the Reserve to make a living and if they had to go away they could leave the children in the residential school and take them home when they return to the Reserve.

"He said that in his opinion if a child had to get a good education it should be in the class room all day because a child could not learn enough doing only half days.

"He said that at present the food at the school was not sufficient and the children do not get enough butter. This is the condition since Mr. Staley left. He said that the reason the children are running away from the school is that the matron is mean with them. He was told this reason by one of the girls. Re:- Complaint - School.
Rosie Wesley, age 14 years.
Daughter of Moses Wesley, Jr.

A number of Indians came to the office to complain about the treatment, at the School, of the above named child.

Present at the Meeting were:-
Chief Enos Hunter
" David Bearspaw
Councillor Isaac Two Young Men
" Jonas Rider
Eddie Wesley
Moses Wesley, Jr., the child's father.
Mrs. Moses Wesley " " mother.

Isaac Two Young Men said Moses Wesley came to him yesterday and told him that his girl had had some trouble at the school and complained to him of the treatment his girl was getting at the school.

Moses Wesley said his daughter ran away from school. When she arrived home she was asked why she came home. She told him that she was doing work with other girls cleaning floors at the school. She said the girls were given occasional tasks as their particular tasks. When she had completed her part she said the matron Miss Hodgson told her to do another part. The girl said she refused to do any more. The girl said the matron got mad with her and told her she was no use around there and to get out of the school. So she went home.

Her father then said he took the girl back to school. He said he and his wife called at the school next day to see how the daughter was. This time the girl said the matron had whipped her for running away. She claims the matron hit her with a strap over the body and shoulders and over the head.

Moses Wesley said he now wants to take his daughter out of school. He does not want her to remain in school and be abused. He also said he did not want his girl to do chores. If she is in school she should be in the class room most of the time and not doing chores.

Mrs. Wesley, when asked by me, if what her husband has told is true said "Yes, I was there when my daughter told her father."

I told them I would investigate the matter at the school when the principal returned as he happened to be away in the city today.

With regard to the foregoing I interviewed the Principal of the school together with the matron Miss Hodgson. I read the foregoing to them. Miss Hodgson said there was practically no truth to the Indians statement. I asked Miss Hodgson to write her report of the incident which she said she would do.
A copy of the Matron's statement is as follows;-

Morley, Alberta.
November 8th, 1946

Mr. J.N.R. Iredele.
Indian Agent.
Morley, Alberta.

Dear Sir;-

I have read the statement made to you by Moses Wesley regarding my treatment of his daughter Rose. I wish to deny the charges made in this statement. I did not punish Rose for running away from school without cause, but did not strap her on the head and shoulders as claimed by her father. This is the only time that I have strapped her although on two previous occasions she had left the school without cause.

Yours Truly,

(Signed) Florence M. Hodgson.
Matron,
Morley Residential School.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

Attached hereto is a report which is self explanatory regarding a complaint of Moses Wesley Jr.

It appears most of the Indians are complaining about the children having to do any work at the school. Owing to the shortage of staff at the school it is impossible to carry on without the help of the senior children to perform some duties and in a way this does not do them any harm, but, such a system means they are only in the classroom no more than half days.

It should be mentioned that at the present time there are no classroom teachers at the school.

Miss Hodgson, matron, and the Rev. G.J. Inglis are doing the teaching along with the part-time assistance of Miss Bartner, the seamstress, and the handicap is being felt severely.

I am satisfied that Mr. Inglis and his staff are doing a splendid job under the circumstances. Mr. Inglis has been doing his very best to obtain two teachers but it seems he cannot get them for the wages he can offer.

It should also be said that the boys are not getting any manual training. They have a very well equipped workshop but no manual training instructor.

There are 34 children in residence at the school and there is room for about eight more pupils, boys. But actually speaking they have all they can manage to do and greatly need a full staff.

J.N.D. Iredale,
Acting Indian agent.

OTTAWA.

Re: Morley Indian Residential School.

The Acting Indian Agent has written to say that the Indians are complaining about the children having to do work at the School.

On my recent visit to Ottawa, I advised you that this school was under-staffed, and Mr. Leadale states that this condition still exists: There are no teachers; the class-room work is very sketchy, as the principal and matron have to do this in addition to their other duties.

It would appear that Mr. Inglis has done his very best to obtain good teachers, but cannot get them for the wages he is allowed to offer.

Attached hereto is a complaint against the treatment of a girl -- Maggie Wesley. I do not think this is as serious as it would appear; however, we would appreciate direction as to the type of punishment that might be meted out at a residential school.

There are 84 children in residence, and it is hoped that the Church officials can and will very shortly obtain teachers, and supply the necessary other staff.

G. H. Gooderham,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,

Minutes of Council Meeting held at the Stony Indian Agency, Morley, Alberta, on March 26th 1947.

X X X X

10. Mr. Hunter: Re Son, request for discharge from School at age 15 years. Stated that by an arrangement with former Principal and Agent, it was agreed that the boy was placed in school at age 6 years, that he would receive his discharge one prior to discharge age. At the same time he complained that as the boy was working outside the school and receiving no class room work, he might as well have him at home helping on his farmstead.

Agent informed Hunter that the matter will be discussed with the Principal, and referred to the Branch for instructions.

11. Tom Simeon also raised the issue of the boys only getting as far as Grade 6, due in his opinion to the half-day basis that the older pupils were subject to. It was explained as carefully as possible that a survey along educational lines was now being conducted across Canada of Indian Schools, and that out of such a survey, a change in our system as to class room work might be made.

X X X X

P.E. Pugh,
Indian Agent.
I beg to state that the following school matters have arisen in connection with the applications of two Indians for the discharge of their children from the Morley Indian Residential School.

1. Gordon Hunter - Pupil No. 90, shown as age 14 years. Father states that this boy entered school 1/8/37, which has been verified from the school returns, and at time of entry to school was 6 years of age. He further states that he was told at the time of entry, that as the boy was one year younger than admission of age, that he would be discharged one year prior to discharge age. The boy is now 11 years of age, and the father requests that he be discharged.

The principal and myself cannot of course verify the statement of the father. Should this boy be discharged at the end of the school term ending June 30th next?

2. Maxine Rider - Pupil No. 0157, shown as age 14 years. This girl truanted from school, and an interview with the father revealed that the girl had complained that she had been abused by the older pupils and that she was bruised when she arrived home. I endeavored to persuade the father to send his daughter to school, but he refused to do so, and has now gone South to work. In checking over the history of the girl it is found that she entered school at 14 years old, has attended since Oct 15th 1943, and in the opinion of the writer, this would appear to be a bad policy to admit Indian girls at that age, and anticipate that they would settle down with young children in classes and be normal, and from the complaint received it would appear that she might have been subject to teasing by older pupils.

Having appealed to the father and her uncle, with no effect, and her return not likely by moral persuasion, and in view of her age, should the truant officers be used, or should she be discharged?

J.E. Hugh
Indian Agent
Ottawa, April 15th, 1947.

Mr. J.E. Pugh, Indian Agent,
Morley, Alberta.

In view of the information contained in your letter of the 4th instant, it has been decided to approve the discharge of Gordon Hunter, No. 50, and Maxine Rider, No. 0157, from the Morley Residential School.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

CRAWLER could not be contacted sooner due to the fact that he was absent from his camp hunting squirrel. Service was made on the 25-12-47. Enquiries made at Nordegg among the Indians shows that Norman LEFRAID and John M. APABAHAN are presently residing on the Pelisko Reservation and have not been at Nordegg.

3. At the present time, it would appear that CRAWLER will not be returning his daughter to School at the beginning of the new term and thus will be liable to prosecution. CRAWLER also advised that his daughter did not want to go back to school which might be another reason why he was unable to raise any money.

4. It is respectfully requested that the writer be advised of any further action that may be required.

This office has been approached by Mrs Enoch
Baptiste, Treaty No 123 of the Bearspaw Band of Indians of
this agency, requesting the discharge of her son, Ronald
Baptiste, Pupil No 117 of the Morley Indian Residential
School.

Mrs Baptiste was supported in her application by three
of the Councillors of the Band, stating that Enoch
Baptiste, the father of the boy, was a cripple and he was
needed at their home to help with the chores, getting of wood
etc.

Ronald entered school at an early age, and is now
in grade six, and his age is 14 years.

One hesitates to recommend the discharge of pupils at this age, especially in view of the fact that this
Reserve has been one of the critical ones in regard to the
schooling of their children.

The father is a cripple and apart from making
willow chairs etc., he is unfit for other work and if the
boy was nearer discharge age, recommendation would be made
for discharge.

May the matter be reviewed, and this office
advised, please.

John E. Pugh, Supt.
Stony Sarcee Agency.
26th March, 1949.

Mr. J.E. Pugh,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Morley, Alberta.

We have your letter of the 22nd instant with reference to the application which you have received for the discharge of Ronald Baptiste, No. 117, from the Morley Residential School.

Presumably, the family has been able to get along without this boy's aid, and there is nothing in your letter to show that circumstances at home have changed to such an extent that they cannot continue to live without this boy's assistance.

In view of his age, we feel that it would be in his best interests to remain at the Morley Residential School for a further period, and consequently, the Department is not prepared to approve his discharge at the present time.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education

Re: Pupil # 0136 Morley Residential School
Bearspaw Band # 202

It is wished to advise that the father of the above noted girl (Joe Kootenay Jr.) called at this office and requested that he be allowed to take home the above noted child. He stated that he would put a younger girl of 7 years of age in school to replace her. He was advised that this could not be done. He then requested the writer to write Ottawa and ask permission to have Kathleen discharged from school.

I questioned him as to why he wanted the girl home and his reply was that girls did not need education and that they did not learn anything at school. He stated that he would like to take her home in order that they could teach her things around the house.

Submitted for your information and reply, please.

(J.R. Wild)
Assistant Indian Agent,

Mr. J.R. Wild,
Asst. Indian Agent,
Morley, Alta.,

Re: Kathleen Kootenay #0136
Morley Residential School

Your file 6-7 (119)

We have your letter of the 29th ultimo with reference to the above girl.

The Quarterly Return of the Morley Residential School shows that she is now twelve years of age and is in Grade 4.

The Department is not prepared to approve her discharge from the Morley Residential School for the reasons given by the father as stated in the second paragraph of your letter.

No doubt the girl will go home for the holidays at the end of the current month but she must be returned to school by September 1st so that she can resume her school work for the academic year 1950-51.

Sir:

I am in receipt of a letter from Indian Agent Pringle, at Morley, enclosing receipts for the sum of $55.00, representing payment by Mr. Staley, Principal of the Big Hill Indian Residential School, for what is termed a 'pure bred Holstein Bull.' Mr. Pringle stated that he has had no word from the Department regarding this matter, but that Mr. Staley claimed he was informed that if the receipts were sent in, the Department would pay for the bull.

Would it not have been better to deal with this matter through the Indian Agent? I cannot imagine what kind of a pure bred Holstein bull could have been bought for the sum of $55.00. At the sale in Calgary last week, Holstein bulls were sold for from $250.00 up; in fact Mr. Christianson, who is here, tells me that a pure bred Holstein bull cannot be bought for less than $250.00. Two years ago the Department bought five pure-bred cows for this school, and a great deal of trouble was taken by the Inspector to get the right sort of animal, and to use a bull of this kind should, in my opinion, be a great mistake. Mr. Christianson tells me that Mr. Staley does not know cattle. Would it not be better to carry on as we have been doing in the past and let such matters dealt with through the Department's officers? You are aware that a large percentage of our School Principals are not competent to buy cattle; it takes a trained man, and I can just imagine what the result is going to be if the price is any indication of what this animal is.

I am not certifying to the account, because I am not sure that the Department did issue instructions of this kind to Mr. Staley, and the Agent is in the same position.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Departmental letter No. 115-1-14 dated the 14th ultimo re a request made by the Principal of Morley Indian Residential School for more live stock for the school, now that they have acquired Lots 7 and 8, Morleyville Settlement, for pastureage.

In the 10th instant I looked over the land in question, and found that it had been over-grazed last year, and probably for years previous, and suggested to the Principal that he complete rounding the fence around same, which he was doing at the time, and allow the land a complete rest this year, to give the grass an opportunity to come up. This he agreed to do on the understanding he would get 15 head of dual-purpose Shorthorn heifers and young cows next Spring.

I naturally informed him that I could not make a promise, but asked him and Dr. W. B. Murray, the Agent, to place an item for this purpose in the Estimates for next year, which I would recommend.

As it is, I do not recommend purchasing more stock this year for the following reasons:

1. The new pastureage acquired needs a complete rest, having been very badly over-grazed.

2. Last year the Principal had to purchase feed for his stock, having been unable to provide same from his fields, and meadows on account of drought. Should same happen again this year, he will be hampered by having more stock and will have to sell off.

Your obedient servant,

Grant Schmidt,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

Mrs. Gussie Starlight referred to by Agent Murray is an elderly widow, Treaty Indian, who transferred from the Sarcee Agency to the Stony. There being no one on the Sarcee to look after the cattle, these were transferred to the Stony Reserve this winter, and the same difficulty as regards feeding and caring for them has arisen there.

Rev. E. J. Staley, who called at this office today, says he has seen the cattle, and having sufficient feed on hand is anxious to increase his herd. Sir:-

I am in receipt of a letter from Indian Agent Pringle, at Morley, enclosing receipts for the sum of $55.00 representing payment by Mr. Staley, Principal of the Morley Indian Residential School, for what is termed a 'pure bred Holstein Bull.' Mr. Pringle states that he has had no word from the Department regarding this matter, but that Mr. Staley claimed he was informed that if the receipts were sent in, the Department would pay for the bull.

Would it not have been better to deal with this matter through the Indian Agent? I cannot imagine what kind of a pure bred Holstein bull could have been bought for the sum of $55.00. At the sale in Calgary last week, Holstein bulls were sold for from $250.00 up; in fact Mr. Christianson, who is here, tells me that a pure bred Holstein bull cannot be bought for less than $250.00. Two years ago the Department bought five thoroughbred cows for this school, and a great deal of trouble was taken by the Inspector to get the right type of animal, and to use a bull of this kind would, in my opinion, be a great mistake. Mr. Christianson tells me that Mr. Staley does not know cattle. Would it not be better to carry on as we have been doing in the past and have such matters dealt with through the Department's officers? You are aware that a large percentage of our School Principals are not competent to buy cattle; it takes a trained man, and I can just imagine what the result is going to be if the price is any indication of what this animal is.

I am not certifying to the account, because I am not sure that the Department did issue instructions of this kind to Mr. Staley, and the Agent is in the same position.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Departmental letter No. 116-1-14 dated the 14th ultimo, requesting me to advise Principal of Morley Indian Residential School for more live stock for the school, now that they have acquired Lots 7 and 8, Morleyville Settlement, for pasture.

On the 10th instant I looked over the land in question, and found that it had been over-grazed last year, and probably for years previous, and suggested to the Principal that he complete repairing the fence around same, which he promised at the time, and allow the land a complete rest this year, to give the grass seed a chance to come up. This he agreed to do on the understanding he would get 15 head of dual-purpose Shorthorn heifers and young cows next Spring.

I naturally informed him that I could not make a promise, but asked him and Dr. W. B. Murray, the Agent, to place an item for this purpose in the Estimates for next year, which I would recommend.

As it is, I do not recommend purchasing more stock this year for the following reasons:

1. The new pastureage acquired needs a complete rest, having been very badly over-grazed.

2. Last year the Principal had to purchase feed for his stock, having been unable to provide same from his fields, due to drought. Should more happen again this year, he will be hampered by having more stock and will have to sell off.

Mrs. Gussie Starlight referred to by Agent Murray is an elderly widow, Treaty Indian, who transferred from the Sarcee Agency to the Stony. There being no one on the Sarcee who would look after the cattle, these were transferred to the Stony Reserve this winter, and the same difficulty as regards feeding and caring for them has arisen there.

Rev. E. J. Staley, who called at this office today, says he has seen the cattle, and having sufficient feed on hand is anxious to increase his herd. If the Department can provide funds, I recommend that the purchase of the eleven (11) head from Widow Starlight be made, and that the money be placed to her credit and given to her in small payments when required, and approved of by the Indian agent. Also, that the four (4) other cows mentioned in the last paragraph of Dr. Murray's letter be purchased, this to make a total of 15 head as mentioned in my letter referred to above. The latter 4 head will have to be purchased from outside. If authority is granted, I beg to ask that Dr. Agent Murray be instructed to make the purchases.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Hoey,

You will recall that you were good enough two years ago to start us off in the fur farming business at the school and while as yet it is perhaps premature to begin to get enthusiastic about it, I can see that even if it is no gold mine it is a promising proposition. This year for the first time we shall be able to carry into account no capital expenditure for supplies or equipment and so I shall be able to furnish you with a much better idea of the situation this fall.

Just a few rough figures. Last year we pelleted 75 mink. The grading of these showed a wide range in quality; the prices realized were all the way from $25.00 to $15.00. Moreover, we had a profit on the sale of $215. This year we have at the present time 50 breeding stock; all this, with the exception of some more males we purchased this spring, from the original investment of 6 mink of two years ago.

The Indian boys have taken to the work in a very fine way and I believe now that at least a dozen boys could find employment if they so desired among the large fur ranches in the vicinity of Calgary.

With average fur prices in the next few years the venture is a good one that we have every intention of giving a full and complete trial.

Yours truly,

Ottawa, April 22, 1941.

Dear Mr. Staley:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 17th instant and to thank you very heartily for the information contained therein.

It was to me and the officials here a source of satisfaction to learn that the mink ranch established at your school a couple of years ago has been reasonably successful. The fact that a number of Indian pupils have taken an active interest in this project is particularly encouraging.

I was very much interested in your comments on the organization created at Morley by a group of the girl pupils. I am hopeful that a number of these organizations will develop at residential schools throughout the Dominion.

I want you to feel free to send forward suggestions at any time with respect to changes that might be made in the course of study. If, in your judgment, a selected number of pupils could be given a short course of training in hunting and trapping, a recommendation to this effect would be very favorably considered by the officials here. A number of safeguards, however, would have to be erected and we would have to guard against the danger that would arise by the average boy looking upon this period as a mere holiday period or a time for rest and relaxation. This is a matter that you might discuss also with Mr. Doucet when he visits your school.

Yours sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

The Assistant Secretary,

Dear Sir,

I write to draw your attention to the position our Church is in in regard to the new Blackfoot Boarding School. We were led to believe last fall that the school would likely be about the 1st December, and urged to have the staff in readiness. We accordingly engaged the Rev. Mr. Gardiner as Principal; he and his wife were on the ground by the first of October. The farm instructor and his wife were there by the 1st December and an Archdeacon has been there since the 1st of this month.

We have no provision for the salaries or maintenance of these people till the school opens and begin to earn a grant, and since acting in good faith on the Department's instructions we desired the staff as early as possible in

Ottawa, April 6, 1912.

Very Reverend Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 25th ultimo in reference to the payment of salaries of the staff at the Old Guns Boarding School.

In reply I beg to say that, if you will refer to the official correspondence with His Lordship the Bishop of Calgary, you will find that the appointment of Rev. Mr. Gandier as Principal was to take effect when the school was ready for occupation. In view of this arrangement it seems strange that the Principal should have been installed in the position so long ago as October 15th last, at a time when there was no immediate prospect of there being any work for him.

As to the Farming Instructor, who has been at the school since December 1st last, I may say that this is apparently the first intimation the Department has had of the appointment, an intimation which under the circumstances would not have been ratified, as there was no prospect of work for such an employee for sometime after that date. These latter remarks apply also in the case of the Assistant Matron.

I have, therefore, to say that the Department cannot assume any obligation for the salaries of a staff.

Your obedient servant,

Ven. Archdeacon J. W. Tims,
Calgary, Alta.

Very Reverend Sir,

The Department is in receipt of the monthly report from Mr. Agent Gooderham on the Old Guns Boarding School, which shows that there are now thirty children in residence. The Agent states that the Principal is handicapped in having to act as teacher as well as Principal and that he finds it difficult to fill both these duties satisfactorily. When he is teaching he is often wanted elsewhere to attend to other matters and the class-room work is thus interrupted.

In view of the enrolment now attained and the prospect of obtaining the full quota in the near future, the Department has to request that you will be good enough to obtain the services of a teacher with as little delay as possible.

The Department is pleased to learn that the members of the staff are performing their duties satisfactorily and that the school is kept in good order.

Sir,

On the Circular "Agreement relating to the Maintenance and Management of Indian Boarding Schools," Clause 18 provides for vacation for the children, not to be less than one month, between July 1st and October 31st.

It was my intention to grant such vacations, but it has been intimated to me that it has not been done in the past and is not desirable in the interests of the school.

I cannot see how any school can be properly managed without a vacation, when the children may visit their homes, when the staff of the school have a short time relaxation. I cannot see how they should be unwilling to bring in the children at the end of the vacations, as the regulations cover all difficulties. It seems a matter of carrying out the regulations.

May I have an expression of the matter from the Dept. of Indian Affairs.

Observe,

[Signature]

M. P. Gardner

Sir,

I have the honour to report that I inspected the Old Sun's residential school on the 15th inst.

I was informed that the previous teacher was succeeding well, had good control of the pupils and that the pupils were daily advancing under her tutelage. I may say that it does not appear reasonable to me to expect efficient teachers to remain for long periods on the small salary offered. When the Department and the various Church authorities were arranging new terms and additional per capita grant I feared at the time that some of the schools would suffer for the want of efficient teachers if no such provision was made and the result has been about what I predicted. When 3rd class teachers are able to command equal to $55.00 per month and board it is not reasonable to expect them to accept about $20.00 per month in an Indian school and where the working hours are usually longer than they are in a country school. If ever the per capita grant to these schools is again considered I trust that the foregoing suggestion will receive attention.

This School, at its present location, has been in operation about 2½ years and during that period there has been about 7 other teachers of one kind and another. Under such conditions satisfactory progress of the pupils in class work could not be expected and in my opinion has not been realized.

If these pupils were proficient in the standards enumerated there would not be much ground for complaint as regards advancement. My impression is, however, that the majority classes under standards III and IV would be more correctly rated if in standard II.

In my opinion this institution has seldom, if ever, had a full staff to properly handle the work. Although Mr. Moore is herein reported to be employed I understand that he had recently resigned. Another male and another female should constantly be employed to keep the outside and inside work up to a reasonable standard. Now the larger boys are expected to help at various duties and too much I suspect without direct supervision. Such supervision I consider absolutely necessary about an institution of this sort for if otherwise they acquire slovenly habits at their work and such habits are most likely to remain with them in after life. The same may be the outcome with the girls and for the want of close and proper supervision when they are engaged at various household duties. Moreover I entertain the opinion anyway that the boys do not spend sufficient time in the class-room. Not more than two boys should be absent from class work any school day and these two for not longer than a half day for stated days in each week. During the season of gardening and farming such a rule might be deviated from with advantage to the larger boys, providing they are closely supervised at such work and idleness on the part of these pupils guarded against.

My dear Sir,

The Rev. Mr. Gaudier has permission from the Bishop to be absent for special Theological studies at Wycliffe College, Toronto - for the period of three months. During his absence the Bishop has asked me to come into residence - & I therefore write to report the fact which I hope will meet with your approval.

A few days before Mr. Gaudier left, two of our older girls ran away, just before the tea bell rang & were not recovered until about 7 a.m. the following day. Mr. Gaudier went himself in search of them, & less than half an hour after the girls disappeared, he reported the same to the parents, & then to the police, who sent out the native scouts. The girls appear to have taken shelter in the house of Harry Reddish Gun, whom they accused (rightly or wrongly) of assault. The statements of the girls & certain evidence given by the school matron, were of so serious a nature that Mr.
Gaudier felt it his duty, with my own approval—to lay a charge against Harry Reddick Gun. The Sergeant of Police, with interpreter—interviewed the girls & collected as much 'evidence' as possible, & it certainly looked very serious. When the preliminary hearing came off before Mr. Vigas J.P., the relatives of Harry Reddick Gun employed a lawyer, who did all he could to upset & 'scare' the girls—who are under 15 years of age—with the result that they opened their lips, and the case was dismissed on insufficient evidence.

I feel strongly that such cases as these should be undertaken by a sympathetic lawyer in behalf of the Crown; on the ground that these poor people are wards of the government.

I can assure you, the utmost vigilance exists among both girls & boys, & that everything we can possibly do for them is being done, for their general good—and I must say the general behavior of our children is really excellent.

This school is located on 160 acres of fairly good land and my impression is that if a fairly practical farmer was employed and retained for reasonable periods, that considerable farm products could be grown and that such products would be of considerable importance with regard to the financial aspect of the school. I do not think, however, that an efficient man for the position of farmer can now be secured for $40.00 per month and board. He would expect a cottage for the exclusive use of himself and wife.

Unless there are very radical changes made at this institution I am not likely to be convinced that the annual expenditure to the Department for this Institution is worth to the interested Indians its cost. Dear Mr. Gooderham,

I have carefully considered the question of a team of brood mares for the use of the school — the purchase of which the Department sanctioned, on the agreement to repay by installments — and I am now anxious to put a different proposition before you.

I have satisfied myself that even with a good big team, I shall never be able to break & disc even 40 acres at this time of the year. I have tried for the last 2 years and again this year to get 60 acres broken for us — I have tried to secure both white men & Indians & have had promises from both — but both have failed me. Only a week or two ago I offered a man with a tractor $6 an acre to break 60 acres for me, he wanted me to provide the gasoline as well, which seemed to me utterly unreasonable, & I am still struggling to get the work done.
My proposition is this— I can buy a tractor (the "Bachelor Boy") and can see my way to finance the same inside 18 months, if the Department will allow the cost of a team to be transferred to the tractor, as the first cash payment. This amount (about $500) would be repaid to the Department inside five years—I think I can promise it in 2½ years, without relying upon crops.

Our pigs will bring us in between $800 and $1000 within the next six or seven months—six of them will be fit for market about September.

We have two young beef cattle coming on, and prospect of more.

The potato crop appears healthy & promising. It should yield several tons more than well, & should yield several tons more than will be required for our own use.

I am not building on any crop of wheat or oats—though they are not yet in a hopeless condition. Our rape is good.

The cost of having to buy oats & hay for a big team promises to be very high. If we can avoid this expense by securing a tractor at once we shall really save a considerable sum.
With the tractor we could not only do our breaking but all our summer fallowing - we could use it with the cutting & binding. We could also use it for hauling our coal from the Station - bring large loads, too save the cost of paying the Brown Transfer people to haul it for us, where purchased by the Carload.

We have examined the "Waterloo Boy" tractor carefully & have watched it breaking some of the hardest lands round here, & are satisfied that it is a good reliable affair. It is very highly spoken by men who have handled tractors for years.

I may add that if we get the machine we shall endeavour as soon as our own breaking is finished, to break land for anyone else so as to bring in cash towards its cost.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 311398 of the 4th inst. stating that Bonus cheques for the month of July will be paid as soon as possible. These will be acceptable, but to learn that we are only entitled to the month of July more than astonishes me.

I am fully aware that under the arrangements for the care of Boarding schools no name would not appear on the pay list of the Department, but the fact remains that I am still teaching Indian children coupled with proper responsibilities from John Smith's reserve, and in addition to this I have your letter before me in which you agreed to pay the transfer from John Smith's reserve to the Blackfoot reserve, as it would be considered a transfer within the Department; and so my mind a transfer within the Department carries with it such benefits that we have previously enjoyed unless otherwise stated. I did not think for one minute that my giving up John Smith's school at a rather unjust desire of the Department that it meant giving up the Bonus cheques and your letter of June 23rd, does not dismiss me from the Department's employ, as under the arrangement for Indian Education with the Churches the practice is for you to state to, in John Smith's case, His Lordship the Bishop of Saskatchewan that my services in the school was not satisfactory, give him the reason and request a new teacher to be nominated. You failed to do this for the simple reason that there was nothing that justified your so doing. His Lordship wished me to remain doing so far as saying that he would take the responsibility of my doing so, and take such action with the authorities of the Church. This excuse a reason to be forthcoming for our removal.

NOV 27 1919
Furthermore in addition to the Bishop's support, after enquiry Mr. Knepp also saw fit to support my claims as, as he says in his letter to me, that he had heard good reports of my work at John Smith's, and on the face of this it appears that you contend that the reports of these gentlemen are not truthful ones.

So far, you have given no reasons for your statement that my services at John Smith's were unsatisfactory, although you have had the opportunity of doing so to the Bishop of Saskatchewan and also myself, and while I greatly desire to know what these charges might be, it is only reasonable that I compare the work of the Indian Agents at the Pagans, and here, as well as the schools themselves, with our late home, and Mr. J.F. Schmidt whom appears to have received directly opposite instructions on school matters to those issued by Messrs Graham & Gooderham. The class work of neither of these schools can touch my work. You have seen fit to issue a diploma to a late pupil of this school and the writing book that is forwarded with this letter is the best of a pile I have found here. My school work was acknowledged by Provincial Inspectors as Prince Albert fair as creditable, and I will submit the John Smith's children's books with these before as if you wish. As a sample of what you might look for I also enclose work of the girls here that I would rather not comment upon. Before I could start the work of the classrooms I had to go to Mr. Gooderham for sisters and pencils for there was just nothing in the schoolroom other than a pile of dirty writing books and a few readers with most of the pages torn out; the blackboards are scratched, the walls are filthy and the floors and windows have not been cleaned in the schoolroom to the knowledge of the kitchen matron for the last four years.

for the eldest girls is such that their discharge will have to be made within a few weeks as maternity cases are just an impossibility in an establishment of this kind. Dear Mr. Scott,

The M.J.J.J. Commission in Calgary could not undertake my appointment to either here or the Petans in July last saying that it would be necessary to await a meeting of the Council of the Society in Toronto to be held during the first week in September. I was then told that the Secretary would visit these schools in November, and would come to some kind of agreement. James Gould reached Calgary last week, and James Stocken went up to see him, and although James Gould wrote me in October saying that he would certainly visit the school, James Stocken has returned from Calgary telling me that James Gould will not be able to visit the place as he thought, and that meanwhile James Gould approves of our being moved here, but for the time being it was considered best that James Stocken had better remain in charge of the school owing to the number of accounts that he would have to present to the Department for work done around the place.

As I expected to meet James Gould I intended to have a good understanding with him, and for the time being I have refrained from writing you in connection with the schools, and I am now placing before the Commission an obligation to work under James Stocken, as it is a point to which they agreed upon before we came to the province.

Meanwhile this correspondence takes time, and in your letter written in July you wished us success in our new undertaking, and so be quite frank I would entirely agree.
with your remarks that there is scope for work at this point, and I trust you will support me in our new work. Neither my wife or I myself wish to be antagonistic to the Department in any way and would like to have some expression of your support.

I have refused the admission of a child three years old, as I find on file a letter of yours saying that no child under the proper age should be admitted unless in the case of orphans when special application should be made. James Stocken sent the child with its father over to the school but I refused its admission on the grounds of age! Is this correct? Somewhat against the wish of James Stocken I have also sent here a girl, Spotted Eagle who was allowed back at the beginning of the year and who was married to an Indian, and yet is shown to be confined. I fear that there are other girls in the same position, and they tell me that their discharge was promised as far back as last February. James Stocken maintains that if these girls are let go, the parents of the other children who are to be brought in will not bring them. There appears to be plenty of children out of school. The town of Gladstone seems to be full of Indian children all ages and abilities, robust, strong and otherwise; every afternoon, some of whom should be in school.

I have had a great deal of cleaning done around the place; it seemed to need it. I would like you to have the walls of the school-room whitewashed. It is still rough plaster, never been painted and is just covered with dark pencil and chalk writing; an amount of scrubbing would improve it; it is the only thing around the place that I cannot clean.

I would like a good supply of Nimblet rope material, half a dozen new hooks in order that each child can have a place in school.

January 12th, 1920.

Dear Canon Gould,

Your letters with inclosures to hand, regarding punishment given to George Baptise at the Victoria Home.

The statements made are far from correct. I could not use a cane on a boy 75 times even if I desired to do so. There was no blood nor any likelihood of their being any, but the boy might have been marked.

George Baptise is an adopted son of Rev. W.H. Haynes. He destroyed or rather spoilt a new outfit of clothes on the Saturday, absented himself from Church Sunday afternoon, and rode the only team we had with an Indian boy to the R.C. Mission five miles away & the following morning with three others run off with the team. We had been drawing water from the river, and for two days the school was without water entirely. Mr. and Mrs. Haynes were very angry with the boy and asked me to give him a sound thrashing on his return. The whip and snaffle was the same as Mr. Giggle had left in the school and was I am told, often using, for far less serious offences than this.

I did not punish the other boys simply because I did not know the Peigan people well enough and I did not wish to cause any difficulty over school matters with them, but as George Baptise was brought up by Mr. Haynes who had, as well as Mrs. Haynes directed he should be punished I thought it correct that I should do so.

My wife and Miss Brooks, boys matron had gone to a great deal of trouble in finding clothes for the boy, and when he came home on the Saturday afternoon he had lost one of a new pair of boots.

The boys had been themselves drawing water and in taking our only horses knew full well the difficulty in which we were placed; my kitchen dept. were naturally hard put to know what to do for cooking, and if George was punished severely he fully deserved it. Constable Wright who is a far stronger man than I wished to thrash them, but I did not allow it because I thought he might be too hard upon them.

I think if Mrs. Thomas Graham had informed Mr. Haynes the details of the case she would have found that it was not important enough to refer to the Department. Had he received a complaint from an Indian it would have been a different matter. Mr. Haynes has since written to me several times and made no comment upon the subject, and had I been unduly severe upon George he would have far more likely have written me about it before placing the subject before the Department.

During the seven years I was at John Smith's the parents complained several times to the Indian Agent that I was too easy with the children which I think will show that I do not punish the children only as a last resort.

I thank you for writing me, and I trust I have made the matter clear.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd) P.H. Gentleman.

P.S. I notice the statement before the Constable was given on Nov. 27th. The punishment was given on Oct. 8th.

Dear Mr. Scott:

Enclosed please find copy of reply received from Mr. P.W. Gentleman in response to my letter concerning the punishment inflicted upon George Baptise, a pupil in the Peigan Boarding School. The case resolves itself, it appears to me, into the following two questions.

First: Is corporal punishment for disciplinary purposes recognised or permitted in the Indian Boarding Schools?

Second: If corporal punishment is permitted at all, was the punishment inflicted in this case unduly severe?

Personally I should imagine that whether permitted or not, it is applied, more or less, in every boarding school in the country. The circumstances reported in connection with this case would seem to indicate that reasonable corporal punishment was fully deserved. The wisdom of selecting one culprit out of three or four
D.C. Scott-2,

and making him bear the punishment due to all, is, of course, another question and one which does not seem to be fully covered by the reasons submitted by Mr. Gentleman, viz: that he having but lately taken over the charge of the School did not know the temper of the Peigan Indians, and that George Baptise is an adopted son of the Reverend W.H. Haynes. The discipline of the school, I am free to confess from my own observations, was, and probably is, in a very low state. The permanent solution of the whole situation depends upon the speed with which the Indian Department is prepared to carry through the scheme of re-organization and consolidation agreed upon. We are unable to secure satisfactory agents for a temporary position such as that which now obtains in connection with the Peigan Boarding School.

Mr. Middleton, has, I believe, the rare faculty of impressing discipline upon the refractory Indian temperament and eliciting, through drill of cadet corps etc., commendable esprit de corps. I am wondering whether it will be possible to place both the Blood and Peigan Institutions under the principalship of Mr. Middleton, thus anticipating the position he will undoubtedly occupy when the two institutions are consolidated.

As soon as the Financial Appeal of our Forward Movement, February 9th-14th, is out of the way, I hope to be in a position to give the necessary time and attention to this important matter. Our whole programme, however, turns upon the plan of re-organization and consolidation in connection with the existing boarding schools in the diocese of Calgary, and I shall esteem it a great favour if you are able to give me precise information con-

Dear Mr Scott,

I recently obtained a little leaflet called "British Columbia News" in an account of a new church being raised on the Kootenay River and an effort to help the Indians who would be found there by the school and mission work with the church.

The article appealed to me, and I thought that we might be able to do something for them. We are doing more than we can at the present time, sending in these people already made friends through our missionary work.

We wrote to Archbishop DuVernay, and after correspondence agreed to block such an effort from the Indians. We believe that the Indians would be helped, and so turned the offer of assistance over to your Agent who appears to be of the same opinion.

I now learn that your Agent has written to Archbishop DuVernay, and myself and wife have not heard from your approval.

I am therefore writing to ask you, upon what grounds or objections recommendations have been rejected?

Your Agent, being an Anglican clergyman in charge of an Agency for Indians, does largely belong to the Church of England. He seems to think that he could be of some use to us together, and so it was not very surprising to you. I would like to point out that the Department seem intent upon taking our little agency away from us.

Having been so long connected in the Department employ, I realize attitudes towards us is more than I can understand, and had I asked for transfer before, again, I feel sure, the same objections would have been raised.

Some three years ago, when I did ask you for a transfer to British Columbia, you wrote me that my request was granted at that time, and I applied to Archbishop DuVernay. However, it did not occur to me that such an attitude would be adopted towards us.

Yours truly,

Dear Mr. Knox,

It is very kind indeed of you to have interviewed Mr. D.J. Scott on our behalf, as mentioned in your letter of the 20th inst., for which I must thank you.

I observe that he does not claim that he has got a vacant position in B.C., a point which his assistant secretary endeavoured to press upon us.

I do not dispute his statement that my wife and I are suitable for our present work. This establishment certainly needs someone who has had experience with Indians, as well as Boarding school work, but when he claims that the position is a good one, he is quite mistaken. At John Smith's our total salary was $1000 a year (including war bonus) house, fuel, and part rations (flour, meat, rice tea soap). Our present salary is $600 a year, and board & accommodation for myself and my wife and as I have remarked before the I.D. do not pay the cost of running the school, so that the managing committee are compelled to buy in the cheapest possible market, which is at present a N.T. contract, which makes the living, the very poorest, and plainest. During the 15 years I have been in Canada this last twelve months has been the worst I have ever put in. In March, I was compelled to go up to Calgary to see a doctor, who told me plainly that such a change of living was having serious effects, so I do not see how the Department can claim that this position is a good one, from the salary point of view.

I notice that the Government have recently put out posters offering $900 cad & board, clothes for raw recruits for the Canadian army, and I have had staying with me a cousin of Mrs. Gentleman's holding an important position with the C.T.F. in the Prince Rupert division, who came down to see us regarding our going to that neighbourhood, she started with the P.H.A. in 1911 at $600, and I myself was receiving $720 from the I.D.
With house, and rations while I was at Duck Lake in 1912. Since that time, I have been able until this year to send part of this home to my Mother in England, and from what I learn from home living in England is very high indeed at the present time.

I think under these circumstances my wife and I can rightly claim that we are receiving an injustice at the hands of the Secretary. Doubtless he believed that I knew what I was taking on when I came here from the salary point of view, but it must be remembered that he dismissed us from John Smith's without taking any steps to ascertain if he was justified in doing so; also that it is impossible for anyone, by merely visiting one place to learn if it has been properly conducted, and my wife and I are having the brunt of a previous principle neglect.

To straighten out this neglect at an increased salary is one thing, but to do so at a greatly decreased salary gives a different viewpoint entirely.

The school at the Nana River came to my notice without being sought after. The authorities on the spot satisfied themselves that we could handle the situation, and wanted us to go, the salary would have been much the same as we did receive, and it would have been at no cost to the I.O., neither would they have had to hunt around for a man for this place, for that rests with the Missionary society.

We will, however, do our best here, and I will see to it that he has no cause to complain, but at the same time, I cannot help saying that their course of action tends towards a state of discontent, which, if I might be permitted to put it that way, is not very admirable to encourage in times like these.

My letter to Mr Scott merely asked why, Mr Jollissions recommendations were not approved of. I make no excuse, merely by no means wished to give any cause for offence, but you will see, my question was merely ended. Thanking you for your good wishes,

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir,

OLD SUM SCHOOL near Gleichen on the Blackfoot Reserve.

The children of this school are generally below par in health and appearance. There are fifty pupils and 70% of them have somewhat enlarged lymphatic glands of the neck. Five of these have scrofulous sores requiring active treatment; first surgical and afterwards tonics and fresh air. In the case of three others with enlarged tuberculous glands, the same treatment should be recommended, while the remaining twenty-five of those affected with this scrofulous disease should have tonics and as much fresh air and highly nutritious food as possible. Milk and eggs should be used very largely and such tonics as Cod Liver Oil and Comp. Syrup of Hypophosphites, or other preparation of iron administered over a considerable period.

One little girl, Emma Big Old Man, has a large tuberculous abscess of the neck and jaw requiring prompt surgical attention, while Mary Red Morning is suffering from tuberculous ulcers of the chest and neck and requires equally urgent treatment. The cases of Felix Little Backbone, Sarah Turning Robe and Annie Cutter should also have prompt attention for tubercular glands. William Calfrobe is suffering from tuberculosis of the lungs, especially of the left apex and should not be in the school, as he is a danger to the other pupils as well as in a precarious state of health himself.

Five boys and three girls are suffering from disease of the eyes sufficiently acute to require active treatment.
Sixty percent of the pupils have scabies or itch, many of them in an aggravated form. The condition has been neglected or unrecognized and has plainly gone on for months. The hands and arms, and in fact the whole bodies of many of the children being covered with crusts and sores from this disgusting disease. Two of the girls - Jean Spotted One and Elsie Many Goods, have sores on the backs of their heads fully three inches across and heaped up with crusts nearly a half inch deep. This condition urgently requires active treatment as it can be cleaned up in a short time with efficient treatment. The clothing and all articles coming into contact with the affected parts will require sterilization by boiling or being well washed with antiseptic. It would be advisable that a competent nurse be engaged to look after this process for a couple of weeks. The building in which these children are housed is far short of ideal. The dormitories are overcrowded and the ceilings are low. The floors are of soft wood and are not varnished and hence very hard to keep clean, especially as the children play through the halls and rooms since there is no proper play room. This also applies to the class room which is a detached building heated by a stove and in no sense modern. This could be made into a fair gymnasium if modern class rooms were provided elsewhere.

There is no infirmary in the building and only two small balconies, but as these are off the staffrooms they are not available for the pupils. This constitutes a very serious defect in the building as an Indian School, for an abundance of fresh air is essential for the health of all children, and much more so for the Indian, who has been for many centuries an out of doors animal and who, in the process of becoming a house dweller, suffers so severely from those diseases which may be classed as house diseases, among these, particularly, Tuberculosis.
Spacious balconies should be provided on the south side of this and all other Indian boarding schools, where the pupils may sleep in the open air, during the greater part, if not throughout the whole year. It is a constant experience that Indian children being taken ill with tuberculous diseases while in schools, and sent home, make remarkable recoveries in the open air life of the tent, even though the surroundings may be otherwise very undesirable. If the sanitarium principle were adopted as far as possible in the construction of all Indian schools and hospitals the result could not be otherwise than gratifying and the prevalence of scrofulous glands and pulmonary consumption would be reduced to a minimum. The beds should be kept in the dormitories during the day in order to avoid dust during the summer and the chilling of the mattress and clothes during the winter when much heat would be abstracted from the bodies of the children before the bed would become warm enough to sleep upon, if the beds had been left out doors during the day. The pupils should dress and undress in comfortable rooms and after being warmly covered in bed should be pushed out into the open air for the night.

P. A. Corbett, M.D.
