MEMORANDUM:

Honourable Sir James Lougheed,

I beg to send herewith important reports from the Indian Commissioner and Doctor F. A. Corbett, of Regina.

When I was in Regina last summer I had an interview with Doctor Corbett, and it was arranged that he should make these inspections. Doctor Corbett is greatly interested in the welfare of the Indians, and his report justifies the inspection.

I regret extremely that it is possible to draw such a comparison between the Protestant and Roman Catholic Schools. The Crowfoot, Ermineskin's and St. Albert schools are all conducted by the Roman Catholic Church, and the Old Sun's and Sarcee are conducted by the Church of England. The comparison does not hold good over the whole field; however, as we have excellent Protestant schools in other parts of the country. The Anglican schools in the diocese of Calgary have always unfortunately been badly managed.

The conditions at the Old Sun's school are disgraceful, and the principal and medical attendant are worthy of serious censure for allowing such health omissions to exist.

As you are personally aware of the general conditions at the Sarcee reserve, this additional information with reference to the school and the Indians there will be of special interest. If this band is to be saved at all we must take vigorous measures and I would propose to turn the school into a hospital and to treat the whole reserve as a hospital area. These Indians have a large reserve and money should be turned into cash as soon as possible and used for their benefit, and the funds we have on hand should be fully used.

It would be advantageous if Doctor Corbett could continue his inspections and visit all our reserves and schools, but as he has a large practice in Regina, I do not think we could expect him to spend the necessary time in making inspectorial visits.

I should like to discuss these matters with you.

Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Superintendent General.

Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 4th inst., file
100-14 re Old Suns Boarding School, I beg to report that I
visited this school on the 9th inst. and made it my duty to
examine the children who had scabies when Doctor Corbett made
an inspection last fall.

As far as I could see all the children were clean, and
no outward signs of the scabies apparent.

One of the worst cases, a boy, whose head and neck were
very bad, seemed to be all right as also were his hands.

The weeks following the visit of Dr. Corbett and
yourself, all the children were bathed and treated by the doctor
and staff as ordered, and this was continued until the infection
was apparently eradicated. Some of the clothing was destroyed
and the balance sterilized.

No children examined for T.B., a boy Wm. Self Robe was
pronounced unfit for school by Dr. Corbett, the boy looks all
right and I would like to know if he should be discharged.

In this connection may say that in leaving there is no
option but to send him home unless it can be arranged to have
him admitted to some hospital.

The girls for whom the doctor ordered cod liver oil are
getting same and seem to be in good health.

No extra staff was engaged to clean up the scabies, but
during the past three weeks, one woman, the kitchen matron,
resigned, there remains now the principal, 3 matrons, and a chore
man, a total of five.

The school shows lack of proper attention and Mr. Gentleman
informs me that the present staff cannot possibly do all the
necessary work.

The Missionary Society have been asked to supply more
workers and I am convinced that a seamstress or a nurse or both
are needed and if this school is to be of proper value, the
Missionary Society, or some other body must keep a staff, which
will make the school efficient. I know that Mr. Gentleman and
his staff have worked hard particularly in the care of the children.

I had all the children vaccinated in December and this
incurred more work; I therefore ask that if in your opinion, this
school is understaffed, that pressure is brought to bear on the
responsible parties, to see that the place is staffed and run as
it should be run.

Your obedient servant,

(SGD) C.H. Gooderham,

I have to acknowledge your circular letter, reference above of the 5th inst., and in reply I must say that fire appliances on hand amount to nothing.

Of the chemical fire extinguishers, supplied when the school was built three remain on their original hooks. Two sets of fire hose are in good order; one I have not seen and the other of the four has bent couplers. The fire hose cannot be used owing to the pressure tank being too small, it is difficult to obtain enough water on the main floor for the children to wash with. We have no fire buckets.

The water system, I pointed out to Mr. Orr during his recent visit, and in the improvements to be made next spring I trust this will be improved, and the hose used.

Meanwhile I would like to have some fire buckets, and hooks provided, buckets should be made to hang, otherwise they would be used for other purposes. I would also like an electric inside gong with push buttons in various rooms, as to ring the only bell in the place it is necessary to go into the basement.

In the past little consideration seems to have been given to this important subject by those in charge, and I should add that I want my instructions to the Department to go into this matter after the improvements are made. Outside of the water pressure tank improvements could be made under the present conditions, which would still be good for the enlarged school, and remain in their places, and I can assure you that in event of any appliances being provided, they will be inspected daily by myself, and I will see that proper care is taken of same.

I might also add that with an enlarged, and almost new staff I have been able, very recently to carry out considerable improvements which should be helpful.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
I have been able to have the children drill, and a system of fire drill will be put into force.

Stovepipes are clean, oil lamps are not used, and smoking by the boys has been stopped. I have had to use stern measures to prevent both boys' and girls' lighting the gas in their dormitories during the nights with paper. The gas machine has one main cut off and when the new dormitories are built up, cut off, will I hope be arranged.

Yours truly,

P. H. Gentleman.

April 2nd;1921.

Dear Dr. Westgate,

I must inform you that somewhat of a serious occurrence happened this afternoon, the laundry building catching fire, which we were only able to prevent from spreading, with some difficulty.

No damage, or loss has occurred as the whole of the flames were around the engine, and up the stairway, and I think that they largely consisted of spilt gasoline, oil, and grease, which gathers round the engine. It just happened that the whole of the staff were close by, and their prompt action doubtless saved the whole school. Had the laundry got a good start we could have never saved the school building.

I should say the Indian Department last fall asked me for a list of fire buckets and details of this kind. I sent my report pointing out that nothing suitable to put out fires seems to have been provided, and only last week, we received from Mr. Graham, Regina, four fire pails, and a five gallon tank with a pump in it.

These things afford us a very small protection, and a couple of dozen buckets and hooks would be none too many, and in addition to this the engine at the foot of the stairs is in a very dark place, and we cannot keep a pressure on the tank. On this occasion we had to use the soft water tank.

I am afraid that I must urge that the present risks in the matter of fire protection, and such matters, be placed before the Indian Department. We feel that the improvements that
Dr. Westgate,

will, I hope, overcome the danger, must not be delayed. The whole difficulty and danger is in the location of the laundry building and engine.

The Northern Electric Co who do the telephone work, also are builders of fire alarm systems, and it would be a great help if a fire gong could be placed on the building. In my report to the Indian Department (which they asked for direct) I mentioned these things, and hoped that they would give the subject consideration.

Such an occurrence that happened this afternoon, could not have happened at the Agricultural School, or the Roman Catholic school. Their engines are both in fire proof rooms. In our case the fire got into the plaster walls under the stairway, and we had to make holes in the wall to get at it.

The outbreak occurred just at four o'clock, all the boys and most of the girls were out for the afternoon with their parents, the whole of the staff happened to be on hand, the matrons in the sewing room, Mr. Pardee and myself in the kitchen, and Mr. Shaw at the engine at the time. Mr. Shaw rushed out of the building with his overalls in flames, which the Matrons caught sight of. Just how it started is not quite clear. Mr. Shaw happened to have a new suit of overalls on. Had it been Smith I do not think he could have put the flames out.

You will, I am sure understand, that an occurrence of this kind makes us doubly careful.

Yours sincerely,

(Sgd) P.H. Gentleman.
The Executive Committee of the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada, having had before it the letter dated January 8th, of the Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, together with the accompanying copies of the reports of Dr. Corbett of his medical inspection of the children in the Old Sun's Boarding Schools, Blackfoot Reserve, and in the Sarcee Boarding School, begs permission to bring the following points in connection therewith, to the attention of the Deputy Superintendent General.

1. That although Dr. Corbett's inspection was made on a date prior to November 25th, 1920, a copy of his report was not mailed by the department to this Committee until January 8th, 1921.

2. That the children in question were, for sometime previous to Dr. Corbett's visit, under the treatment directed by the local medical men. Writing to the Executive Committee under date November 25th, 1920, the Acting-principal of the School says in part -

"Mr. Gentleman and Mrs. Bloomer spent a great deal of time treating sore places on the girls. Dr. Corbett pronounced this to be 'itch' and claimed that the treatment directed by the local doctor was entirely wrong."

and further:

"Mr. Scott .........can be assured that the directions of the local doctor had strict attention and that Dr. Corbett's desires are being carried out."

The Executive Committee submits therefore, since the children in the Old Sun's Boarding school were, prior to the visit of Dr. Corbett, under the care of the local medical men and that the latter's instructions were carefully observed by the School's staff, that the staff cannot fairly be held responsible for the results of the wrong diagnosis made by the local medical men.
That the report of Dr. Corbett presents a strong condemnation of the adequacy and satisfactory character of the building occupied by the Old Sun's Boarding School - a building erected wholly by the Department.

The Acting-Principal writes that the recent work done in connection with the heating system has improved matters but little if at all, and that during a recent cold snap he was obliged to go himself and spend a great deal of time in the boiler room in the effort to secure some fair degree of heat in the building.

4. That the Executive Committee, at its meeting on May 5th, 1920, adopted the following resolutions:

"That a sub-committee be appointed to interview the authorities of the Department of Indian Affairs with regard to the condition of the children in the Sarcee Boarding School and the future of that Institution. Consideration of the estimates being deferred pending report of this Sub-committee."

and that on the 27th of the same month the Sub-Committee in question - C.B. Nicholson, Esq., M.P., and the General Secretary - had an interview with the Deputy Superintendent General in his office on this matter. At this interview the Deputy Superintendent General agreed to the views set forward by this Executive, through its representatives to the effect (1) that the physical condition of the vast majority of the children in the Sarcee Boarding School made it imperative that the institution should cease to be operated as a boarding school, and (2) that the few healthy children should be transferred to the enlarged building at Old Sun's.

The conclusions arrived at and accepted at this interview were set out in the letter dated June 2nd, 1920, of the General Secretary to the Deputy Superintendent General as follows:

Dear Mr. Scott:

In view of my departure for England tomorrow, I am placing before you, in writing, the results, as I understand them, of the recent interview which you kindly granted to Mr. C.B. Nicholson and me, as follows:
The heating system of the Sarcee and Old Sun's Boarding schools to be immediately overhauled, and if necessary new systems to be installed adequate to the heating of the building.

Provision to be made in the estimates of the Department for next year (a) for the erection, on a site to be selected of the new joint boarding school for the Blood and Blackfoot Indians, (b) the remodelling and enlarging of the building used by the Old Sun's Boarding School to make it possible to remove the girls dormitory at least from the ground floor and to provide such additional accommodation as may be needed for the Anglican children on the Blackfoot Reserve who are not now in the School, and for a few Sarcee children who are free from tuberculosis infections; providing that satisfactory arrangements can be made for the transfer of the latter from the Sarcee to the Old Sun's Boarding School.

I am writing that you will agree with the above as stating the result of our interview, and thanking you for your ready kindness and sympathy in our efforts to place the Anglican work on behalf of the Indians upon a more efficient basis.

Believe me,

Yours very faithfully,

(signed) S. Gould,
General Secretary.

and acknowledged by the Deputy Superintendent General in his reply dated June 10th, 1920.

the Executive Committee therefore resolves

(1) That this Executive Committee, having brought the physical condition of the children in the Sarcee Boarding School to the notice of the Department, as long ago as last May, renewed its grant to that institution for the current year with great reluctance, and only as an interim measure, pending the taking by the department of the action recommended that the Institution
We disestablished as a boarding school and provided with a staff and equipment necessary for the efficient medical treatment of the children. Further, that this Committee now earnestly request the Deputy Superintendent to put this change into effect at once, releasing this Committee of responsibility for the Sarcee Boarding School at a date to be set, which date should not be later than April the 1st of the Present year.

(2) That this executive Committee requests the Deputy Superintendent to issue, forthwith, an order prohibiting the continuance of the practice, at the Old Sun's Boarding school under which the Indians have been in the habit of taking their children out of the school for Saturday or other short periods of absence; that the Department define the holidays or vacations during which either the parents, or guardians, may remove children from the school, or during which the principal may give them leave, that no local official, either of the Department or of the Missionary Society shall have power to vary the rule in question and should the Indians, under the enforcement of the rule carry out their threats to remove their children from the school, then the Department shall assume the responsibility for the return of the children, so removed, to the school, or, in the event of their non-return by the Department, the Department continue to pay the per-capita grant involved toward the maintenance of the school.

(3) That this executive Committee assure the Deputy Superintendent General of its earnest desire to place the Indian boarding school, under the Church of England in Canada, upon a basis of efficiency in the shortest possible time. It points out to him the fact that its ability to accomplish its aim depends almost altogether, upon the replacement by the Department of such wholly unsatisfactory and worn out buildings as those at present occupied for boarding school purposes on the Blood and Peigan Reserves, and upon the remodelling, enlargement and re-equipment of such modern but very inadequate buildings as those of the Old Sun's School. This Committee further, expresses its great
regret that the limitations placed upon the plans of the Department by the very great calls which the Minister of Finance is required to meet in other directions, has prevented the Deputy Superintendent General from placing in his estimates for the forthcoming year, a sum sufficient to cover the whole of the building operations agreed upon as urgently needed, at the interview of May 27th last, and as set out in the correspondence quoted above. This Committee further urges the Deputy Inspector General to make financial provision as soon as possible for the erection of The New Joint Boarding School for the Blood and Peigan Reserves, and, following the enlargement and re-equipment of the old Sun's Boarding school, give the claims of this Joint Institution, right-of-way as far as the Church of England in Canada is concerned, over all other needs for building.

(4) That this Executive Committee submits to the Deputy Superintendent General the following immediate proposal,

1. This Committee to select, employ, and pay a thoroughly qualified nurse who shall be appointed to the nursing care of the Indian Children in the Boarding Schools under this Committee. The nurse to travel from Institution to Institution seeing that the instructions of the medical officers of the Department are properly carried out, and spending in any one institution the amount of time which any special need of the children there may require.

2. The Department to be responsible for (1) the nurses travelling expenses between institutions and (2) the needed medical and surgical supplies

3. If this proposal is accepted and found to be satisfactory in operation, this Committee will in due time, if the need be shown to exist, consider sympathetically the appointment of a second nurse on the same conditions.

January 14th, 1921.

Dear Mr. Scott,

Your letter dated January 8th enclosing copy of Dr. Corbett's report on his inspection of the children at the Old Sun School and the Sargee School received.

These serious matters were considered by our executive committee yesterday, and I enclose herewith the Committee's action on the communications noted. The Committee's action is so very full that I do not think it necessary to add much by way of further comment. I need only emphasize the point that the directions of the local doctor were carried out by the members of the staff and the conditions described by Dr. Corbett must be ascribed to the wrong diagnosis of the local medical man. Speaking from an entirely personal standpoint, and in the light of thirteen years medical work in Palestine, I found it very difficult to appreciate the following statement by Dr. Corbett "Two of the girls - Jean Spotted One and Elsie Many Goods - have sores on the backs of their heads fully three inches across, and heaped up with crusts nearly half an inch thick". As a condition caused by scabies, this description struck me as quite unusual. I read the extract, I may add, over the telephone to a very prominent medical authority in Toronto and he at once said that scabies did not affect the scalp. This, however, is after all a minor point, and I have no desire to discuss the diagnosis of the local medical man or of Dr. Corbett. Having just returned from the school, however, and noted its condition - conditions which were confirmed, as you told me, by Mr. Orr - I must ask
to be permitted to say that I think Dr. Corbett's account to be somewhat over-emphasized.

I shall regard it as a favour if you could let me have an early reply concerning the definite recommendation included in the resolution of the Executive Committee.

1. With regard to the Sarcee Boarding School, the acknowledged physical condition of the children in this school making it imperative, in our estimation, that they should be placed entirely under a medical regime, - a regime which must of necessity involve considerable expenditure and require the services of specially trained agents and, therefore, should be, we think, conducted directly by the Department, though as a Missionary Society we should be glad to cooperate in any possible.

2. The question of the short leave system for the children, which has been current in the Old Sun's School. You will remember that I brought this matter also, on a previous occasion, to your notice and I trust that there will be no difficulty in the issuing of necessary instructions by the Department.

3. With regard to the nurse; we find that while there is a very definite need for the inspection and nursing care of the children, we do not find that there is sufficient work at any one institution to require the services of a qualified nurse all the time. We, therefore, trust that our proposal will meet with your approval as the best immediate solution of the need.

I may say that the Acting-principal of the Old Sun's School advises us that the Indian Agent, on the request of Canam Stocken, has applied for the admission to the school of one or more children who were decidedly under age.
Our Executive Committee laid down the ruling for its own Agents (1) that children under the specified age (laid down by the authorities of the Indian Department) could not be admitted to any school, without the express permission of the Executive Committee and, further, that the principal, or Acting-principal, and not the Missionary, must be the person to submit applications through the proper channel to the Department for the admission of all children. I am glad to know, from the letter of the Acting-principal, that you agreed with the above views of the Executive Committee concerning the admission of under-age children and that you declined the request submitted by the local Indian Agent.

We are engaged in the active search for a competent farmer for the Old Sun's school, and I shall be glad if you are in a position to let me know what steps have been taken by the Indian Commissioner with a view to securing, for the use of the school, the additional lands.

Believe me,

Yours very truly,
S. Gould,
General Secretary.

P.S. If you think that under some system of special grants sufficient to enable the Missionary Society to pay the qualified agents needed, and to meet the other required expenses, we could conduct, as a Missionary Society, the Sarcee Institution as a Sanitarium, I shall be glad to submit your views to the Executive Committee. Needless to add, we are most anxious to do all in our power to meet and alleviate the distressing conditions existing at present.

S.G.

I would particularly draw attention to the Inspector's remarks relative to the inadequate training in farming given to the boys at these two schools. The Principal of the Old Suns school has had no agricultural experience, and knows very little about the care of stock, while the Inspector's report with regard to the farmer and stockman attached to the school is not very encouraging. The prospects of the boys receiving good grounding in agriculture and stock raising under the tuition of these men are not very bright. As I have pointed out to the Department on previous occasions, training in agriculture and the care of stock is of greater importance to Indian boys than classroom work as it is to these occupations they must look for a livelihood when they return to the reserves. Our experience has been that school graduates, in many cases, are very much less capable as farmers and stockmen than Indians who have not received a school training. This is disconcerting, and unless Indian boys receive an education which they can put to practical use when they return to the reserves the period spent by them at school represents a waste of time and money.

I am of the opinion that the remedy for this state of affairs lies in the Department insisting that only men who are practical agriculturists be appointed as principals of our boarding and industrial schools, and trust that this matter will be taken up with the Church authorities as it is too bad that all these schools do not function as they should.

I am disappointed to hear from Mr. Christianson that the teachers at the Old Suns School are not qualified in so far as that they have not received Normal training. The reports of the Provincial School Inspectors on Indian schools have been in the majority of cases unsatisfactory, and these gentlemen have invariably stressed the necessity for employing as teachers in our schools only men and women who have received Normal training. I am sure that this matter is one which will receive earnest consideration from the Department.

Dear Sir:

With reference to our conversation re the weedy condition of the Old Sun's School farm, and the report made by the authorities of that institution that the cause of this state of affairs was owing to the weedy condition of the Indians' farms adjoining their land, I have to point out the following facts:

The Nome Farm No. 1 lands, under my charge, lie directly alongside the school lands, only a wire fence dividing them, and are also in close proximity to the Indian farms complained of, notwithstanding which, they were, and are, remarkably clean and free from weeds, and called for no adverse criticism from me. The Indians on the farm refuse to agree with one exception among the oldest and best farmers on the reserve, and have their farms in very good condition, taking everything into consideration. The exception I refer to is the Yellow Horse place, which, as you are aware, owing to the death of the owner, we had some difficulty in getting properly worked. I would also point out that the worst infestation of the Old Sun's School land came from especially the mustard family, while the Indian farmers have had most trouble with the Russian thistle. These Indians go very carefully through their crops when growing, and pick all the weeds in sight, preventing them to a great extent from becoming matured.

I may also mention that last year, last spring, I pointed out to Mr. Smith, who was then farm instructor at the school, the dirty condition of the wheat seed he had purchased, and strongly recommended him to put them through the fanning mill, offering him the use of my outfit to do so, as they had none of their own. He did not take advantage of my offer, but the result was that his wheat came up badly, breaking, and summerfallow, the result being a very dirty crop. I would also say that during last harvesting season, the mustard rolled off their land onto mine in such quantities, that they had to send their boys on more than one occasion to clear them up, in front of my binder, to enable me to get my oats cut. The Indian farms adjacent to them had difficulty with their binders through weeds, while the school people had the utmost difficulty in cutting their crop at all. I would like to say that the present school authorities went to a great deal of trouble, pulling and thinning weeds on their lands last fall, and certainly did their best to better conditions.

Yours truly,

(Signed) J.C. Hutchison,
Farm Inst.
Sir,

Your letter of 6th ultimo, No. 1-1, re weeds on Indian farms near Old Sun's School to hand. The Rev. I attach herewith a report by our farm instructor who lives near the school and has four Indian boys under his charge. His reports are regularly given to me and I am well aware. He "Yellow Indian" farm has been taken over by the Old Sun's School this spring. Last year Canon Stocken who then lived on the edge of this farm pleaded for the widow when I threatened to take the farm from her, and let the young Indians work it properly and finally convinced that she should remain. He provided the Canon took the responsibility of having the cultivated land properly worked. Unfortunately the land received very little cultivation and was overrun with Russian thistle when winter set in. May say that same was true of the original Old Sun's farm which had never been properly cultivated since I assumed office in 1870.

The present farmer at the school, Mr. Brown, is doing his best. He has over 300 acres of cultivated land to work with poor equipment. He is a man I would judge of 65 and his assistance to the Indian boys. The farm instructor is Mr. Jones, is highly incompetent and has little or no control over the boys. Now what can be expected under such conditions.

If the church authorities have at any time, no many grounds for complaint as to weeds, lack of supervision, or incompetency among this Agency staff as has been evident at Old Sun's School, I will consider myself a failure. The Department can rest assured that the Indian farmers adjacent to this institution will not pollute the school farm with weeds provided the staff of this Agency get the proper supervision and cooperation. I would strongly urge the Indians to be better people in all their walks of life.

Dear Mr. Scott,

With reference to your letter of June 13th, (104-1-1), and my reply, of even date, to the last paragraph of the same, I now beg to submit to you for your consideration, extracts from letters just received from Mr. Stone and Mr. Shaw, and written in connection with the rather damaging statement which you quoted as emanating from the Blackfoot Agency's Farm Instructor in connection with the farming operations at the Old Sun School.

1. Mr. Stone's Letter.

"As per instructions I beg to report as follows re management of farm:

Mr. Shaw left Xmas 1921. Prior to leaving he bought Seed Wheat of the Alberta Pacific Elevator. There is no doubt that both Mr. Shaw and Mr. Brown are competent farmers. The Elevator belongs to a respectable Company, and a heavy penalty is attached to the selling of dirty seed. This seed was sown on the Blind Bird place, also on our own farm. It took three of us all day, and every day the whole summer to pull the Tumbling Mustard on the Blind Bird place. Our own farm was free of mustard and is free today. On the evidence we discussed any idea of the seed being foul. Although the land sown to wheat on the Blind Bird place was fresh broken 1921 we could only come to the conclusion that the mustard was the accumulation of the dry years we have had (since 1916 I understand)."

The Yellow Horse place is now being worked by this school, the bulk of it is under corn which is coming along nicely. I would point out that the present school authorities mentioned at the end of letter from Dept. of Indian Affairs is the same farm management that has been from 1/1/22 to date of mailing this report."

(signed) Jas. Stone.
Duncan G. Scott, Esq., C.M.G.

2. Mr. Shaw's Letter.

"I have your letter of the 19th inst., also enclosed copy from the Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs. I can only refer to the Agency Instructor's reference to the wheat I purchased in the spring of '21. This statement is not quite correct. I have no recollection of his ever having even seen the small amount of wheat needed for the little field of about 16 acres, which I spring sowed. The wheat came up in good shape, and as clean a little crop as I ever saw. On July 1st '21 it got half eaten by the ground, came up again, clean, and was cut for fodder—3 or 4 loads, as far as I remember. There was no new breaking, or summer-fallow, on all our property. After that I started in to break on Blue Bird place, followed all of our own, and fall plowed what wheat land Blue Bird had used for wheat. This was all double harrowed, the breaking double plowed, and kept black. I did not fall plow the oat ground, as spring plowing was best. I can only say that Mr. ——— the Agency instructor—with whom I got along splendidly—must have got mixed up a little with the 2 amounts of seed wheat purchased, as we bought the seed wheat for the big crop in the fall, when much cheaper. I do not at all recollect his pointing out condition of wheat, as there is more time in the early spring months to clean all seed for sowing. I left the school in December.

I have very kind remembrances of both Mr. Gooderham, and the instructor. They gave me every assistance in their power, and their advice was very valuable to one, unused to both climate and soil.

Accepting this as early as possible, so that you may not be delayed in any communications you may send.

Yours faithfully,"

(signed) G. Murray Shaw.

The statements set forth above correspond very well with my own knowledge and recollection of the whole situation, and I must here re-affirm my confidence in the ability and integrity of our Society's agents who are, or who have been, responsible for the farming operations at the Old Sun School since the beginning of the year '21. They laboured indefatigably and patiently with the limited amount of equipment at their command, but their best efforts were constantly being negatived, to a very considerable extent, by the growth of noxious weeds on the adjacent Indian Holdings. However, as Your Department very kindly made arrangements last year for

Believe me,

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have just returned from the Province of Alberta, where I have been for nearly three weeks. I visited the Blood, Peigan, Sarcee, Blackfoot, Hobbema and Edmonton Agencies, and eight Indian Boarding Schools.

BLACKFOOT AGENCY.

I next visited the Old Sun School. I was disappointed to find that the Instructor who was there last summer has been taken away. The management of the outside work is left in an old man seventy years of age, of whom you have had a report by Mr. Christianson last July. He is not at all qualified to carry on the work that is necessary. The grounds surrounding the building were very untidy. It might be said they did not want to put the time on the work in view of the fact that we are tearing down some of the buildings. This, to my mind, is no excuse. It was not just the old building, the whole Institution presented an untidy appearance.

The stable is too elaborate altogether. The same accommodation could have been provided for half the money that was spent. I think it was $10,500 - $6,000 would have provided the same accommodation.

The measure for the winter was not removed from the end of the litter carrier. This should have been taken away once a week. The explanation given was that they require a truck to do this work. I do not agree with this, a wagon would have done as well as a truck.

There are eight head of cattle in the stable, two of them Holsteins and six short-horns. The cattle were in fair condition, but the flow of milk was inadequate.

I am afraid this school will not be successful, I hate to have to write officially about this matter, but I am satisfied that I waited sufficiently long before expressing myself. I think the Principal conducting an Institution of this kind should have practical experience in matters of academic training, but he should also have a practical knowledge of outside work, sufficient to be able to direct affairs and not be guided entirely by the advice of his outside staff. I regret to have to bring this matter to your attention, but I would not be fair to myself or the Department, if I did not express my opinion on this matter, and I can assure you it is not expressed hastily.

(Sgd.) W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 17th instant No 104-1-1, in which you state that the reports concerning the farmer at the Old Sun Indian Residential School are unsatisfactory, and that it is extremely desirable to take immediate steps to secure a proper incumbent for that position I beg to inform you that your letter was placed before the Indian and Eskimo Commission of our Society at a meeting held here yesterday, and I was instructed to request you to kindly furnish me with the grounds of dissatisfaction on which those reports were based. As you mention in your letter that the present farmer is "an old gentleman" I can only infer that rejection is taken to his appointment on account of his age. In this connection however, I should like to point out that Mr. Brown, the present farmer, while much older than Mr. Minnely, the graduate who occupied a temporary appointment as Farm Instructor at this School last year, but is now Farm Instructor at the Elkhorn School, is by no means so old a man as to be unable to discharge the duties attached to his office with satisfaction to our Society. He is a younger, more vigorous, and fully as capable a man for this appointment as men who are occupying similar positions at Roman Catholic Indian Residential Schools in the Province of Alberta, and as those appointees still retain their positions and are not conducting farming activities on so large a magnitude as we are undertaking at the Old Sun School, the unsatisfactory reports which you have received, coming as they do, after the reports of a similar nature which reached you last year in the same connexion, appear to me to be discriminatory against the Church of England.
At the March meeting of our Indian and Eskimo Commission arrangements were made whereby the Principals of our Society's Schools in the Prairie Provinces, where farming activities are carried on, should have the benefit of the expert knowledge which Mr. Minicelly, B.S.A., the Farm Instructor at the Elkhorn School possesses; and as he has already, at the request of our Commission furnished the Principal and the farmer at the Old Sun School with instructions as to how the farming activities are to be conducted this year, I have every reason to believe that these will be carried out with satisfaction to your Department as well as to our Society.

Our Society maintains four male agents at this institution, viz., Principal; Vice-Principal; Engineer and Farmer. During the summer months the Engineer, while his duties are not so heavy in the main building, will keep the school grounds in order and take charge of the garden.

Arrangements have been completed for planting about 5,000 trees during the spring and summer, and it will be a matter of very keen regret to our Society, as well as to the Principal and his staff, if any readjustment of the personnel of the staff should be made necessary through the receipt of adverse reports, such as the one referred to in your letter. I am hoping, however, that after you have received the explanation which this letter contains, you will find that further "remedial action" is unnecessary and that I may have a statement to that effect from you.

Dear Sir:

Dear Sir:

Re the Old Sun School.

With further reference to your letters of April 23, and September 5 (104-1-1) relative to the Old Sun School, and my replies dated April 29 and September 11, respectively, I now beg to inform you that during my recent tour of inspection to a number of our Society's Schools in the prairie provinces, I visited the Old Sun School on the 15th and 16th insts., and gave much careful consideration to the criticisms of Mr. Gibney, the Acting Principal, made by your Commissioner. In your letters referred to above, your Commissioner is reported to have stated, inter alia, that -

(a) Mr. Gibney is a very impractical man.
(b) He is absolutely incompetent for his job.
(c) The School is at a standstill if not going back.

As statements such as these, especially when they are made by one holding the office of a Commissioner, cast a serious and disfiguring reflection on our Society's system of administration, I am of the opinion that it would be quite in order for our Society to request your Department, before proceeding any further, to instruct your Commissioner to furnish in writing some, at least, of the specific grounds on which his statements are based. You will agree with me, I think, when I state that it is a comparatively easy thing to do to make certain damaging statements, but that it is not always so easy a matter to prove to the satisfaction of others that such statements are true. The absence of any definitely specific grounds on which the Commissioner has based his statements in this matter, renders it very difficult for me, and would also, I believe, for anyone else to examine the situation from his point of view. I can, however, and have pleasure in doing so, furnish you with certain facts about Mr. Gibney and the work which is being accomplished at the Old Sun School and after you have examined these I am of the
opinion that you will receive a different and more favourable impression than the Commissioner's statements are likely to convey.

1. WITH REGARD TO MR. GIBNEY'S QUALIFICATIONS.

I beg to state as follows:

(a) He was King's Scholar in 1906 at the Church of Ireland Training College where he qualified as a Teacher and subsequently taught school for six years in Ireland in the capacity of Principal.

(b) He holds the Diploma of a Trained Teacher from the Board of Education in Ireland.

(c) He is a graduate in Theology of Wycliffe College, Toronto, where he obtained the L.Th. degree, and is in full Orders in our Church.

(d) He is 38 years of age, slight of build but energetic and active, enjoys good health, and has had charge of churches at Chapleau, in Ontario and Caron in Saskatchewan.

From the above facts it seems to me to be clear that Mr. Gibney possesses qualifications which must surely help to fit him mentally, morally, and physically for the position he now holds, and that consequently he can not be so "absolutely incompetent" as your Commissioner states.

2. It is, however, with the work itself which is being accomplished, not only on the School farm, but in the class room and other departments as well, that one would naturally look for evidence of Mr. Gibney's fitness for the position which he holds, and in this respect I beg to state that, in my opinion, the results are not disappointing. A few of these, out of many which might be mentioned, are as follows:

(a) The excellent state of the health of the children at the time of my recent visit, their good behaviour, general tidy appearance and happy expression of countenance all impressed me as being such as could only be secured in a thoroughly well and wisely managed School.

(b) The large number of Indians, larger than I had ever seen before, including parents of the children and others, who came to the School to visit the pupils and participate in the Sunday Services and their many expressions of satisfaction with the care which the present staff were taking of the children in residence, appealed to me with considerable force as evidences that the Principal possessed the good will of all, and was accomplishing a greater work in this respect than any of his predecessors had done.

(c) With regard to the class room and all the indoor work no written report from the School Inspector was available, but I was
informed by the Principal that Inspector Boyce had reported verbally to the local Indian Agent that good progress had been made during the period since his last visit. As evidence that progress was really being made, and that the School was not at a standstill nor going back, I may state that at the Calgary exhibition held last July, this School, in proportion to the number of exhibits sent in, carried off the second largest number of prizes, even in competition with exhibitors from the Province of Manitoba.

At the Regina exhibition held in July-August last, the School secured 22 prizes—a large increase over last year, and of these 8 were of the 1st, 7 of the 2nd, 6 of the 3rd, and 1 of the special classes.

At the local exhibition held at Gleichen last September it was still more successful and was awarded 26 prizes, 9 of the 1st class, 8 of the 2nd, 8 of the 3rd, and 1 special.

While all of the above mentioned prizes were won for classroom and domestic science work, I find that this School was likewise very creditably successful in securing prizes for farm and garden produce. Owing to the cost of sending these exhibits to remote centres, they were entered only at the Gleichen Fair and succeeded in being awarded no less than 36 prizes, of these 15 were of the 1st class, 12 of the 2nd and 9 of the 3rd.

A School that can show a record of at least 92 prizes in one year, 35 of which were of the 1st class, 30 of the 2nd, 25 of the 3rd, and 2 specials, does not appear to me to be accurately described as being "at a standstill" much less as "going back."

In addition to this I found that despite the early snow fall which visited all that part of Alberta this year and caught many farmers unprepared for it, the silo was full and a sufficient supply of hay, oats, and other green feed put up, either in the loft of the barn or elsewhere, to carry the stock through until the Spring. I found also the small but inadequate root cellar as full as it could conveniently be with turnips, potatoes, beets, and other vegetables and ready for the use of the children and the staff. These things were, to my mind, just as they should be, and I am utterly unable to understand how a Principal who had managed so well could be described as either "impractical" or "incompetent." My difficulty in this respect was increased also rather than diminished, when I remembered that Mr. Gibney is quite competent to handle gasoline engines, and has handled all those installed at this School on occasions when the engineer had been absent or laid up with illness.

In my opinion, therefore, and that of the members of our Commission to whom I have communicated the above information, I beg to state, Mr. Gibney is discharging his duties as Acting Principal of the Old Sun School in an efficient and satisfactory manner, and that it would be not only a grave mistake but an act of great injustice to have his appointment cancelled.
When the Old Sun School has been linked up with the power from Bassano, the same as the Crowfoot School has been, it is probable that the present engineer may be discharged and a younger, unmarried man engaged in his place who will not only look after the furnaces in the winter, but along with the present farmer, devote practically all of his time to the work of instructing the boys as to how to obtain the best results from the garden and the farm.

In order to do this with the best prospects of success, it will be necessary to have the further equipment in the way of buildings already promised, namely - an implement shed, a poultry-house, pigery, granary, an ice-house, cold storage room and dairy, and a new and larger root cellar, and I very much hope that these may soon be supplied. When these have been provided and the Acting Principal and his staff receive from your Commissioner the whole-hearted cooperation and encouragement which they deserve, I am persuaded that the work of this School will be an unqualified success.

Believe me, Sir,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Field Secretary M.S.C.C.

TBRW/IMC
The cost of this work I figured to be about $900.00. It may, however, transpire that we will not be able to use as much of the old material as we figured on at first. In that case some additional material may have to be purchased. The cost, however, will come well within the $1,000.00 which was authorized by the Department.

I beg to bring to your attention the fact that I reported on this school in April, 1927, which was just a short time after the Church authorities took over the institution subsequent to its being remodelled. At that time I found Mr. Brown and Mr. Stone occupying positions outside men at the School, the former looking after the farming operations and the latter attending to the stock. I stated in my report that these men were not capable of doing the work. On my next visit to the Agency the services of a Farming Instructor named Mr. McMinieley who is now at Elk Horn - had been procured, and at that time I was very well impressed with him, and felt quite sure that he was capable of doing good work at this Institution if he received the proper backing. During this last summer I was aware that Mr. McMinieley had been transferred to Elk Horn School, but naturally I was under the impression that he had been succeeded by a man who was capable of filling his place. You can imagine my surprise therefore, when I visited the School, to find...
old Mr. Brown in charge of all the outside work. He may be a fine old man, and I do not doubt that he is, but that is not a sufficient recommendation to enable him to handle a large number of Indian boys in addition to a farm which should provide the training for these boys that is an important part of their education.

The school might make good use of Mr. Brown to look after the gardens and the chickens etc., but he is not suited for the position he now occupies. Another thing, he could not get any assistance from the Principal, who is a man inexperienced in outside work, stock raising and in running an institution of this kind.

The farm work at this school is a huge joke. The crops raised last summer were grown up with weeds, and the Agent informed me that in a plot of cultivated land by the side of the road, one could not tell the corn from the weeds. No attempt had been made at cultivation. To give you an idea of the lack of management here I might mention that the crop raised last summer was practically all standing in stock. I presume it was the intention of the authorities to use this crop for feed. There was an empty loft in the barn and this could have been used as a place in which to store the crop. Instead of doing this, however, the grain was left standing and they are now picking it out of the snow. The authorities cannot
cannot come back and say that the work at the school farm is no worse than the work done by the Indians, because out of 14,000 acres which are under cultivation by the Indians there is only one small farm belonging to an old man, that has been as poorly worked as the school farm. This is no excuse for the latter's present condition.

I do not think this matter should be treated lightly by the Department. A serious situation exists here. Unless some steps are taken to change the management the place will become so infested with weeds that we will be severely criticised by outsiders. Not only that, but the work in general will suffer.

When the first frost came, the water froze in the pipes in the barn, owing to the fact that they were neglected as the hay loft was empty and very few stock were in the barn. I also noticed that the litter carrier was out of order. The premises around the stable and barn yard are in a very untidy condition and no effort is being made to remedy this state of affairs. This deplorable situation should not exist in an institution of this kind. They have first class school buildings and everything else should be in keeping and up to the same standard. I have no personal grievance against Mr. Gibney. I think he is a fine man, but he is not getting the results he should. He is not aggressive, and lacks the force that is necessary to carry on the work of an institution of this kind successfully.
OLD SUNS SCHOOL, C.O.F.E.

As per your instructions before I left, I arranged for the tearing down of the old out-buildings and using the material, as far as possible, for the erection of other buildings. I made arrangements for the erection of the following buildings:

- **Ice House**: 16x12, with three thicknesses of lumber, capacity about 18 tons of ice.
- **Chicken House**: to be moved to a new site and repaired.
- **Pig Pen**: to be built, size 18x70 with four pens.
- **Implement Shed**: 30x75, with a garage in one end for one car, and store house for oil, gas etc.

This space will provide for all implements they will need in connection with farming operations.

This will complete the number of buildings that are necessary at the present time. At some future date they may need a shed for stock, but at present they have not enough cattle to fill one side of the barn, so the necessity for a shed in this connection need not be considered for some time.

Dear Mr. Scott:

With reference to the matter of the deficit in connection with the operation for the year 1923 of the Old Sun Indian Residential School Blackfoot Reserve, and the agreement arrived at during our recent conversation that, in view of the special circumstances and agreement which led to the enlargement of the school, the deficit in question be shared between the Department and the Missionary Society, I beg to say that the total cost of operation for the year 1923 was the sum of $14,585.19, while the total receipts from per capita grants amounted to $7,123.00, leaving a net difference of $7,462.19 which sum, I understand, is to be shared equally between the Missionary Society and the Department. Allowing for this payment by the Department, I find that our total deficit in connection with the operations of the Indian Residential Schools under the Society will, at the close of this year at December 31st, be a total amount in excess of the sum of $40,000.00.

On my way recently to the Coast I stopped off at the Old Sun School, having in mind particularly the adverse reports made by Mr. Commissioner Graham with regard to the capacities and qualifications of the Rev. Mr. John Gibney, Acting Principal. After looking fairly fully into the situation I agree with the conclusions arrived at by the Rev. Mr. Westgate as already submitted to you. Mr. Gibney is not what might be described as a show man. He does not, on casual acquaintance, reveal his best qualities. I was persuaded, however, that he possessed excellent qualifications for the post, having, in particular, a strong sympathy with, and understanding of, the Indians both adult and children. He is steadily gaining a very strong influence over the adult Indian population on the reserve; this influence is shown in several directions not only in the fact that the pupilage of the school is steadily increasing being, I think, 69 at the time of my visit. Here appears, therefore, to be a fairly good hope that, in a reasonable time, the school may be brought up to a capacity attendance of 80 from the reserve itself.

I was surprised to find that Mr. Commissioner Graham had sent an Inspector to arrange for the pulling down and reconstruction of all the outbuildings, other than the new barn, and that this was under way. The temperature had already fallen, during a recent cold
spell about twenty below zero. Since my return the public press has reported still colder weather in Alberta. My point is that it is very difficult to understand why the work in question should have been postponed, apparently by the Commissioner, during the whole of the summer and autumn months, when it might have been carried out with speed and satisfaction, and delayed until the winter months thus subjecting the administration of the school to the great annoyance and difficulty of having its outbuildings dismantled at a time when the weather was ranging many degrees below zero.

I hope to come to Ottawa in the near future, probably some day next week, for further talk with you if convenient.

Please accept this expression of my every good wish for the New Year and

Believe me,

Yours very faithfully,

I beg to draw your attention to the fact that on the 17th of April last, just one year ago, you informed me that you were drawing Dr. Westgate's attention to the advisability of securing a proper Farming Instructor for the Old Sun's Indian Residential School without delay. I replied to your letter under date of April 24th, stating that I had great doubts whether the Principal at the Old Sun's School had the qualities necessary to conduct an institution of that kind, as he had no knowledge whatever of stock or farming.

On the 28th of April I received a letter from you, dated the 23rd idem, which was in reply to a portion of a general letter which I had written to you on the 3rd of that month, and which dealt with the unsatisfactory management in the case of the Old Sun's School. In this letter you informed me that the Department was corresponding with Dr. Westgate concerning the Principal, and referred me to your letter of the 17th in which you stated that action was being taken to secure a Farming Instructor. As no action had been taken I wrote you again on the 9th of September, saying that up to that time, five months later, I had heard nothing regarding the matter. This letter received no acknowledgement.

Surely this is an important matter, and deserves the immediate attention of the Department. We are spending a large sum of money at this institution. We have some 40 boys there who are supposed to be acquiring a knowledge of practical farming. We are only wasting the boys' time, to say nothing of the girls. They are being taught nothing in this line.

I would ask that the Department deal seriously with this matter. A whole year has passed and no action has been taken.

Dear Sir:-

In reply to your letter of the 14th inst., no. 104-1-1) relative to conditions at the Old Sun's Indian Residential School and with further reference to the Deputy Superintendent General's letter of January 7th last on this same subject I felt to inform you that our Society, in conformity with the request contained in the letter has endeavoured to strengthen up the outside staff of the school by the appointment of a farm instructor in addition to the farmer who is already there. The name of the farm instructor who has been appointed subject to the usual period of probation is David James MacGlashan, who was at the time of his engagement by us on the C.P.R. demonstration farm at Strathmore Alberta. In a letter received from the Principal on the 9th inst., he is described, in part, as follows:-

"About 42 years of age, about 6 feet in height, and of military bearing. During the War he held the rank of Captain and was for some time Overseer of Internment Camps in Oxford and Berkshire, England. His record which I glanced through is very good. He directed some thousands of prisoners in these camps in breaking up and cultivating the land. Before the War he was engaged in farm work in Scotland, and since coming to Canada some three years ago, he has been engaged in farming until he entered the service of the C.P.R. on their Strathmore Farm. He is thoroughly conversant..."
with mixed farming operations, filling of silos etc. He is also very much interested in the raising of stock and poultry. His manner is firm, but kind, with a slight Scotch lowland accent. He speaks as a man of considerable education. Taking everything into consideration I have no hesitation in asking him to come to us as farm instructor and Vice-Principal. He will also be able to direct the boys in their sports. He is a married man without children and his wife is still in England. She is prepared to come out to him as soon as he has secured permanent employment. She is an English woman of good education, a good musician, and also has a good knowledge of poultry raising. Mr. MacGlashan is anxious to have his wife with him and as she is only 34 years of age, of good health and physique, I would recommend that the Commission's general rule not to engage married couples be not enforced in this case, and that Mr. MacGlashan be allowed to arrange for his wife to come out during the latter part of the summer or early in the fall.

As the concern of our Department appeared to be centered so far as I can understand it on the farming activities of the school you will see that our Society has made a faithful effort to have these placed on an unquestionably satisfactory basis, and I trust the engagement of the farm instructor as mentioned above who will direct and assist the farmer in the farm operations may prove satisfactory to your Department.

Believe me, Sir,

Yours very truly,

L.B.R. Westgate

Dear Sir:

I have received your letter of the 17th inst., No. 104-1-1 in which you refer to a certain report on the Old Sun School, making special mention (1) of an insufficient staff, (2) and the inability of the Principal to satisfactorily undertake the full duties of Matron-in-charge on account of her own three small children and (3) stating that the Medical Officer finds it difficult to locate the cause of the lack of energy which the pupils were said to have manifested.

As you have not given me the name of the author of this report I am unable to ascertain his capability of judging whether the staff is sufficient or otherwise. However, as you have taken the trouble to write me in this connection I can only conclude that the author of the report is one of your responsible representatives and that his opinion is worthy of attention.

Before going any further I should like to assure you that our Society will give to this matter, as it endeavours to do to all similar communications received from your Department the careful attention which it deserves, and in due course I shall have placed in your hands a report of action which has been taken. In the meantime I think I can confidently assure you that the health of the children and the work in general at this institution are not suffering to any extent through a shortage of food or through an inadequate staff. With regard to the food supply I have vouchers in this office which show
that under this heading bills have been met exceeding $800.00
and other orders placed with bills outstanding at the end of
the quarter which brought the total amount spent to well over
$1000.00.

With regard to the staff I may state for your infor-
mation that this school has at the present time three male
agents under permanent appointment and one probationer who will
proceed to Hay River when navigation opens.

It has also six ladies including, of course, the wife
of the Principal who is acting as Matron-in-charge. This
appointment was, of course, only given to her from the middle
of this month when the Matron-in-charge proceeded on furlough to
England. The Principal's wife is a thoroughly conscientious and
a thoroughly capable woman and although she may have to devote
sometime to the care of her own children she is able with the
assistance of the other five ladies to devote all the time that
is necessary to the duties of her office as Matron-in-charge.

For your further information I may state that the positions held
respectively by the other members of the staff are as follows:
Senior teacher, Junior teacher, Boys' Supervisor, Girls' Super-
visor, Kitchen Matron, and it seems to me that a staff of nine
permanent agents and one under temporary appointment ought surely
to be sufficient to manage a school which has under seventy
pupils. Our Society however, will consider the question of
adding another lady member to the staff in accordance with your
suggestion, but at present I am quite unable to see how this can
be done until a separate residence has been built for the
Principal. This it seems to me is one of the most urgent re-
quirements at the present time. After my last visit to this
school I embodied a recommendation to this effect in my report
of our Indian and Eskimo Commission and this recommendation was
unanimously approved. I have also reason to believe that your
Commissioner will support this recommendation as he spoke to
the Principal at the time of his last visit of the necessity of
the same. In making this recommendation I would like to sugge-
st that the most convenient and economical way for this residence
to be provided would be through the erection of an annex to
the east end of the main school building. This arrangement
would not only keep the Principal in close touch with the in-
stitution both day and night, but it would admit of the one
heating, lighting and water systems being extended to serve the
annex as well as the main building at a minimum of cost.

If provision were made for the Principal in this way
his wife and children would be removed from the main building
where they are now obliged to live in circumstances which cannot
be beneficial to their own health and which might be consider-
ably aggravated if Mrs. Gibney were not allowed to discharge
any duties and to have no official position whatever. Ladies of
high moral character and with the musical and other qualifica-
tions which she possesses do not abound in great numbers in these
days, and so long as she is obliged to live in the main school
building I am of the opinion that it would be a great mistake
not to allow her to continue to discharge the duties of the
office which she at present holds.
There is, as you will know, another very serious obstacle in the way of our Society appointing an additional lady agent, and that is a financial one. The total earnings of this School through the per capita grant for 1924 amounted to $3,255.80. As the total operating expenses according to our auditor's report amounted to $13,500.67 you will see that our Society had to find the sum of $5,244.87 to keep the institution going. As our Society is not in a position to pay out so large a sum from year to year not only for this but for other institutions you will see how difficult it is for us to increase our operating expenses until some provision has been made for increasing the School's revenue. At the present time the per capita grant is fixed at $140.00. If this were increased, as I think it should be, to at least $170.00 the question of adding an additional member to the staff would be easier of solution.

I have written at considerable length in the hope that the explanations which I have given may reveal to you some of the difficulties which confront our Society in the administration of this School, and I trust that your Department may not, under the difficult circumstances which now confront us, press too heavily for standards which our resources will not admit of attainment.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

I note also that you will favourably consider adding another lady member to the staff, but that you believe a residence will have to be built for the principal. There are some funds available for building purposes at this school this fiscal year, and I will therefore urge Mr. Indian Commissioner Graham, of Regina, with reference to the advisability of providing a principal's residence without delay. I am pleased to have your suggestion that the residence, when erected, should be attached to the east end of the main building.

With reference to the last paragraph of your letter, I wish to assure you that the Department understands the difficulties which confront Your Society in the administration of the Old Sun's Indian Residential School. Rest assured that we will not press for standards of instruction and care which will not admit of attainment because of any inadequacy of physical equipment. It is our aim to provide the necessary buildings, etc., at all Indian residential schools, so that the work among the youth of Canada will make progress. As funds are available, this intention will be carried out, and all we expect of your Society and the management of the individual schools is to do the best possible under the circumstances. You will understand, however, that the efficiency of personal services is not largely dependent on physical equipment at these institutions; and from time to time I will draw to your attention, when necessary, reports concerning the qualifications of members of the staff at this and other schools that are managed by your Society.

Sir:

I beg to submit the following report for the month of March 1925:

OLD SCHOOLS: was visited on the 30th. Classroom work is good and pupils show good progress. It cannot be said however that this Institution is orderly or spotlessly clean. The children lack pep and the staff does not appear to be able to cope with the situation to me, it is considered unfair to the Institution and to his family, that the Principal's wife is on the staff. Mrs. Gibney has three small children, the oldest not over three years of age and no person can persuade me that the Indian School, where these children mingle with the pupils, is the place for them. I cannot see how Mrs. Gibney can undertake her official duties unless she neglects her family or details her family duties to another. This school is inefficiently staffed and under present conditions, I cannot see that much remedy will be made.

There is a house formerly occupied by Canon Stocken, not far from the school, where, I think the Principal and his family should live.

G. H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.
I am enclosing herewith Agent Gooderham's report on the Blackfoot Agency for the month of March.

I would particularly draw your attention to what the Agent says regarding the condition in which he found the Old Sund's school. With regard to that portion which deals with the Principal's residence being in a school, I agree entirely. I remember this when the school was being built, and also a year ago when I was in Ottawa, when we were discussing the building of the St. Paul's school on the Blood Reserve. If the Department are building any more Protestant schools my strong recommendation is that the Principal live in a detached house.

However, the above matter is not the most serious question. What are we going to do about these children who are unfed and are not getting a proper training? Now, it is very important that we get something done here, as we cannot go on in this way. I have been protesting against the management of this school for three years now, and it seems most unfair to the Indians to spend money and get the results we are getting.

I would also refer you to Nurse Lorne's report on this school, in which she says the children are not getting enough proper food, that the lavatories are in poor working order, and unsanitary, and that many of the children are medically neglected. I am further informed that a report of the children with swollen glands, who do not have a resident doctor, should be had. However, I am writing to the Agent on this matter.

Your obedient servant,

W. H. Graham,

the operation of the Old Sun's School has been the subject of conversation on

(1) An interview towards the end of the year 1924, the res-
ulting agreement, as I understood it, was, in accordance

I felt that certain agents were required to look after the remaining School property, including buildings, live stock, and the farming and gardening activities, and trust that this arrangement may meet with your approval. At a later date, after the report referred to above has been received, and our Commission have had an opportunity of considering the same, I hope to be able to submit certain suggestions and recommendations to you with regard to the transfer of the pupils after the summer holidays to other institutions, where they could remain until a new School has been provided.

I may say that I have already written to the Principals of the Elkhorn, Onion Lake, St. Cyprian, St. Paul's and Mackay Schools asking them to consult the local Indian Agents with regard to the question of receiving some of the pupils from the Old Sun School,
and let me know the numbers which could be accommodated in this way. The information contained in their replies will be embodied in the full report which I will make when all the information referred to above has come to hand. As this is the first School which has been destroyed by fire since these institutions came under the control of our Society, the members of our Commission who are responsible for their administration are feeling the loss very keenly. The merciful deliverance, however, of all the pupils and staff agents is something which they cannot soon forget and they heartily thank God for it.

Believe me,

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Scott:

With further reference to my telegram to you on the 27th inst. and your telegram in reply on the same date, I now beg to state that I received yesterday from the Rev. Archdeacon Tipp, who was asked by our Commission to proceed to the Old Sun School and report on the cause of the fire which destroyed this institution, and also from the Rev. P. H. R. Gibney, the Principal of the same, full statements in this connexion.

The Archdeacon arrived at the school on June 26th, and his statement reads, in part, as follows:

"There is absolutely nothing left of the building except the concrete foundation and a lot of bent and twisted iron-work in the basement, the remains of bedsteads, pipes and radiators. The fire was first noticed about 8:30 p.m. smoke was seen to be coming from the ventilator of the old roof cellar, used partly as a dairy, at the extreme south end of the building. Mrs. Douglas, the Kitchen Matron, went at once to the door leading to the Dairy, beyond which a lot of raffia and sacking (bale covering) had been stored away, and found the smoke issuing from within overheating. An alarm was at once phoned to Gleichen, and in a short time the fire brigade and nearly 100 civilians as well as the Indian Agent and his staff were on the spot. Meanwhile the children, 50 of whom were in bed, were all got out in an orderly manner and Mr. Gibney had turned the house down the ventilator on the roof of the old root cellar. The fire brigade on arrival broke through the roof and used their chemical engine on the fire which burst into flame as soon as the roof was opened up."
The water pressure soon gave out from the low pressure tank, and when the chemical engine required re-charging there was no water except from the well at the barn.

As soon as it was seen that the fire was going to take the building, the civilians who had brought scores of buckets with them set to work to save the Principal's residence on the one side and the Church on the other, by carrying water from the barn. This supply however was cut off when the fire affected the power line which ran the pump motor.

An attempt was made to use dynamite to blow up the portion of the building between the main building and the annex with a view to getting more time to salvage the effects but this failed of its purpose.

The whole of the effects in the Principal's residence were carried out of doors, but fortunately the building was not touched, thanks to the men who protected the walls and roof with blankets and water.

There is only one opinion as to the cause of the fire and that is spontaneous combustion from the pile of raffia and old sacking in which the babies had come, stacked away in the old dairy or root cellar. The exceptional rains we have experienced lately had carried the damp through the roof and probably assisted in creating a condition which issued in the combustion.

The raffia, etc., had been placed here, when the old class room was pulled down, as the only place where it could be stored.

Too great praise and gratitude cannot be given to the Indian Agent and staff, or to the civilians from Gleichen who all rendered what assistance they could.

The pupils were all dispersed to their homes as soon as the parents could be notified, with the exception of a few of the older boys who are retained to assist in the farm work.

The children all had just what they could carry out with them. The fire drill regularly held seems to have proved its value for on the alarm every child jumped from bed, wrapped itself in a quilt, picked up its clothes and marched down the fire escape.

In a few cases where the parents are destitute and have no bed or other clothing for their children suddenly returned to them, it is really necessary that some assistance should be given them in the way of more quilts and clothing for the children.

The Indian Agent kindly placed an empty house at the disposal of the Farm Instructor and his wife, and the Hospital authorities offered shelter to all the other members of the staff."
Mr. Gibney's statement reads in part as follows:

"Why this time you will have in hand Archdeacon Tim's report re our recent regrettable fire.

The Archdeacon's report is so comprehensive and as he went over all details carefully with me and then the report was read over in the rough to me, I find that the ground has been so thoroughly covered that I can only corroborate what he has said. We had only been in a half hour or so from a rehearsal of closing day exercises at the front of the school building when the smoke was noticed. No time was lost in sending in the alarm, which was answered promptly by the fire-brigade and townspeople. Our heartbreaking difficulty was the lack of water pressure. An early attempt was made to blow up by a charge of dynamite the hind end of the building but without effect. This of necessity drove all out of the building and consequently any thought of saving our splendid supply of clothing was put aside. This was a bad blow to me as many of the children have very little in the way of clothing and a number of the parents are not able to make adequate provision. This fact is constantly coming up before me. I feel sure that the Indian Dept. will assist us as far as possible to meet needy cases, and Mr. Agent Gooderham has requested me to note such cases carefully.

All children have gone home. We are, of course, having relays of the bigger boys to assist in farm work. Those will be looked after at the Mission House. We may have also to make certain provisions for some of the older girls. All the cooking, etc., for these will be looked after by Mrs. Gibney assisted by Miss Hobson who is very pleased to remain on with us. Certain emergencies will arise, of course, from time to time, which I shall have to refer to you for advice.

Mr. Gooderham has been exceedingly kind and considerate in every way, and in fact the agency staff as a whole and very many of the townspeople could not have been more kind. I am thanking one and all publicly through our local paper."

The above statements were presented to our Commission at a meeting held yesterday, and I was instructed to forward the same to our General Secretary in Toronto, with a strong recommendation that he should endeavour to arrange an interview with you at the earliest date possible, and take up such urgent and important
questions as the provision of clothing for the pupils, their transfer, or otherwise, to other schools after the summer holidays, the building of a new school, the means of maintaining a small staff to look after the livestock, crops, remaining buildings, etc.

My letter to our General Secretary is going forward today, and as he will no doubt communicate with you in the very near future, I do not see that there is anything further which I can do at present.

Our Commission will be glad, however, to have any suggestions you may wish to offer, and to co-operate to the fullest extent of their power with your Department in overcoming the difficulties which have arisen so unexpectedly through the loss of this valuable institution.

Believe me,

Yours very truly,

Following Departmental instructions preparations were made to open two day-schools for Protestant children.
