Dear Sir:

Last summer when the Deputy Superintendent General visited Winnipeg, he presented to me a verbal request that the Acting Principals of the Old Sun and the St. Syrian schools, as well as the Female Instructor at the latter institution, should be replaced before energetic and competent men. During my visit to your Department last month, further reference was made to this matter in my interview with the Superintendent of Indian Education, and I undertook to submit it to our Indian Residential Schools' Commission for their consideration. The Commission met on the 6th instant, and after carefully canvassing the whole situation, instructed me to inform you that, in their opinion, drastic action of the nature contemplated, should rest on a written statement, embodying specific reasons for the same, and not merely on a verbal request. If, therefore, you will kindly furnish me with the statement suggested, I will submit it to the Commission at their next meeting. In making this request the Commission desired me to inform you of some of the major considerations which influenced them in connection with the same. Two of these were as follows:

1. Their anxiety that no injustice or any appearance of such, should be done to any of the parties concerned, and
2. The necessity which is laid upon them themselves by the constitution setting forth their duties of submitting to the Society's Executive Committee, all matters relating to the appointment, transfer or dismissal of Principals.

They would assure you of their hearty desire to conform to the wishes and instructions of your Department at all times, but would like to feel well assured before final and drastic action is taken in a matter of such great moment, as the one in
question, that such action is not only fair and fully justified,
but that the Society has some prospect of being able to effect
immediately the improvements in the School management which
your Department apparently desires.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

FOR THE MONTH OF MAY, 1929, ON THE OLD SUN'S INDIAN
DAY SCHOOL.

This temporary day school is conducted as well as Mr. Gibney can but I hope it will not be long before a residential school is erected. The pupils come irregularly and when they come from a distance, often do not arrive until late forenoon. Advancement in class-work is slow under ideal conditions but is negligible under temporary arrangements.

A splendid mid-day meal is served but this is possible only as long as the threshing cockear is available.

OLD SUN'S WEST END DAY:

This temporary day school is not so bad. The building is used only for school work and is centrally located in a farming district. Good progress in school work is not possible as so many children attend irregularly despite our endeavours and inducements. Grades 1 to 4 are taught and most pupils are in the first three. The teacher and the Matron do their best with class work and mid-day meals. I feel, however, that the temporary arrangement should be replaced by the permanent school as early as possible.

OLD SUN SCHOOL OPENED, GLEICHEN

Prominent Members Clergy Officiate at Colorful Ceremony

Forty-four years ago the Indian department gave $500 towards the erection of a Church of England boarding school on the Blackfoot reserve.

Tuesday saw the formal opening of its successor, the new Old Sun residential school, to be operated by the Church of England, and built at a cost to the government of about $250,000.

This splendid school, the last word in modern educational convenience and efficiency, is entirely fireproof, has large airy rooms, delightful sunny playrooms, four well-equipped classrooms comfortably furnished, and two dressing rooms for the staff, and kitchen, supply room, etc., all fitted with the latest electrical devices, make the new building one which is probably not excelled anywhere in Canada.

The dedication of the school chapel preceded the formal opening and the services of dedication and thanksgiving, followed by a celebration of Holy Communion, conducted by Bishop Sherman, assisted by Rev. Canon Gale, Archdeacon Time, Rev. Canon Gale, Rev. Canon Gooderham, Rev. R. Gilney, Rev. C. F. Ilves and Rev. J. W. House, principal. The bishop intoned the prayer suitable for the rest of the proceedings.

A large number of Indians gathered outside the new school and marched in procession around the building. Among the Archdeacon Time, Indian Agent Gooderham, Mrs. Cross, diocesan president of the Women's Auxiliary, and other clergy, followed by visiting Indians, the girls, then the boys, and a great number of other Indians, men, women and children, all of them adorned with blankets, shawls and blankets, added color to the proceedings. There were also many visitors from Calgary and Gleichen.

Keys presented

At the front entrance the keys were formally handed over by the Indian agent, representing the government, to Mr. Wood, representing the missionary society.

There was a short service of singing of the doxology, followed by the singing of "God Save the King," the doors were opened and all filed into the school.

Indian Agent Gooderham, in a speech, indicated his belief that said that the wish of the government regarding the Blackfoot children should have a well-rounded and balanced education, with due regard for their religious and moral development.

Archdeacon Time spoke of his own Blackfoot and English of his early experiences there in days gone by. Canon Gale, speaking in both languages, conveyed greetings from St. Paul's Cathedral.

The native catechist, Paul Puka, said that he himself wanted to go to school, but was prevented by his parents from doing so because they thought the white man's ways. He warned and give their children instructions, and exhorted the boys and girls to take advantage of the opportunities.

Chief of the Blackfoot, Duck-Chief, then bestowed on the school the name of "Natsol," meaning "The Shining One," the school is named, and with whose permission Archdeacon Time and Mrs. Cross visited the Blackfoot reserve. This portrait was the work of N. Grandmason.

Blackfoot Indians Have Fine School

Modern Residential Institution Is Named After Chief Old Sun

By CAROLYN CORNELL

Within a short distance of the old chief's deathbed in 1877, in Blackfoot country of Indians, entered into treaty for the sale of Canada's vast western lands miles of their ancestral territory in southeastern Alberta, there stands today a beautiful residential school for the education of descendants of those Indians who subscribed to the treaty.

The school, situated near Gleichen, Alta., was built by the government of Canada and is administered by the Anglican Church.

It is called Old Sun School, in honor of Chief Old Sun, leader of the North Blackfoot, one of the signers of the treaty.

A fine portrait of the chief, painted by Mrs. E. C. Crockett, wife of Chief Crockett, was unveiled at the opening ceremonies by Mrs. Crockett, daughter of Chief Old Sun.

Her Majesty's representative, the chief justice of the North-West Territories, Mr. Justice Macleod, and his contingent of the North-West Mounted Police, presented the keys of the new school to Bishop Weigelt, who was representing the missionary who had been engaged by the church to build the school.

The new Old Sun residential school, recently opened by the Anglican Missionary Society near Gleichen, Alta., gives an idea of the magnificent building being erected by the Dominion of Canada for her Indian wards.

Named After Chief

The new school is one of the few Indian residential schools after the name of the tribe being educated in connection with Blackfoot. In recognition of its close association with the British Empire he was presented with a sword by Queen Victoria for Indian Chiefs, signatures of which are on display.

The Blackfeet are among the most prominent of the North American aborigines, owning more than 600,000 acres of land, according to recent reports.

The tribe now has a population of about 3,000 and annual rentals amount to more than $10,000.

Chief Old Sun

Two Ceremonies Linked

Martha Crockett, who is a prominent worker in the Woman's Auxiliary of the Anglican Church, has performed a connecting link between the two ceremonies, both so interesting, yet picturesque, both in their own way.

In 1877 representatives of the Canadian government came to great Blackfoot confederacy camp, in all their glory, and the chief, Mr. George Gough in paint, feathers and powdered buckskins, the Indian on the Blackfoot reserve, who then a young missionary, said no words, but stood watching, hoping that he, the chief, might come in to view.

Bishop Dedicates Charge

Right Rev. L. H. Sherman, Bishop of the Diocese of Rupert's Land in Canada, officially took over the charge of the new school for administration.

He was assisted by a delegation headed by the energy Mayor of Calgary, Mr. J. B. McCauley, agents of the school, with the Indian children from the old school to the front entrance. They were followed by the teachers and many of the Indian parents from the Reserve. Numbering 400 pupils, the school is now providing excellent facilities for the children.

Archbishop Tied

In an address to the gathering Chief Crockett, who died in 1925, gave the hand of friendship to the old chief gave the archbishop.

Nurses Are Graduated

Indian girls take very kindly to nursing, and in this case two girls from the Shingwauk Institute have graduated and are now employed in the New York Hospital. Four are in training in various hospitals, one in Ottawa and one in Nelson, B.C.

One girl is now employed in one of the schools administered by the mission. She graduated recently from Trinity college.

Others are being graduated from the Shingwauk agricultural and other regular colleges.

One girl is employed in the residential schools. One girl, from the residential school in Ontario, is a graduate of an Anglican residential school.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report, dated 16th January, 1930, from the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, submitting that the main building of the Old Sun Indian Residential School on the Blackfoot Indian Reserve, in the Province of Alberta, was destroyed by fire in June, 1928. MEMORANDUM

Dr. McGill,

The main building of the Old Sun Indian Residential School, on the Blackfoot Indian Reserve, was destroyed by fire in June 1928.

The Indians, wishing to expedite replacement, petitioned the Department to take from their funds the sum of $50,000.00 which, with $40,000.00 provided by Parliament, enabled the rebuilding to proceed. Approval of the loan was granted by P.C. 207 of January 29th, 1930. It was proposed that the loan should be refunded to the band funds within the next two fiscal years but no payments have been made.

As the band funds would have received interest each year at 5% I think provision should be made to recoup band funds to the amount of interest which has accrued and in future, or so long as the loan continues, provision should be made each year to pay over the interest on the loan.

To protect the interests of the Indians for money invested in the building, it was decided, in June 1933, to place fire insurance on the building. A policy for $60,000.00 was placed and the premium of $600.13 was paid from band funds and this must be added to the original loan of $50,000.
If interest had been allowed each year, the band funds would have benefitted the next year by the interest on the same, which means really that compound interest must be allowed at five per centum the rate allowed by the Government on Trust Funds.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to report on an inspection of Old Sun's Indian Residential School at Gleichen.

At the time of my visit I found there were 99 children on the roll, but only 92 present. It will not be necessary for me to report on the health of the children, as the Department are aware of the results of the T.B. clinic held there last fall, when it was found that many of the children were suspected of having tuberculosis, and a number of others were found to be active cases. Certain instructions were given by the doctor in charge of the clinic, as to the method of treatment, such as rest and special food, &c. I found in talking to the Agent and Doctor Windsor that the instructions were being carried out with good results.

I found the school building in very good condition, clean and tidy and everything in order. The machinery and equipment are all in A1 shape.

Appearance of children - Good.

Clothing - Ample; Several changes for both girls and boys.

Doctor Harold W. McGill,

Deputy Superintendent General,

OTTAWA.
The girls are given the usual training carried on in all Indian Residential Schools — that is to say, those girls who are not T.B. suspects.

Regarding the training of boys, a shop has been fixed up in one of the rooms of the school and the boys receive a certain amount of manual training in the way of carpentering, &c. The boys also help with the farm work, looking after stock, milking cows, &c. It might also be interesting to the Department to note that arrangements have been made to irrigate some of the land used by the school! In co-operation with the Agency an irrigation ditch was built last fall connecting up with the C.P.R. irrigation ditch, and using the overflow from this ditch. This gives the agency sufficient water to irrigate the flats down by the North cow camp, and also gives the school water to irrigate approximately 200 acres. This will be of great assistance to the school, as for the last four years they have had their crop dried out and have had to buy feed. I was down looking over the irrigation project, and both the school and the agency have certainly done well in bringing this about, as it has meant considerable voluntary labour.

The school have about 100 acres of crop in that can be irrigated, and they have broken about 50 acres of new land.

They have 40 head of cattle, most of which are cows, and they were milking 22 at the time of my visit, which gives them all the milk, cream and butter that they require. They have 6 work horses and a few pigs.
The Staff consists of 4 male members, including the Principal, and 7 lady members—a total of 11. I consider they have a fairly good staff at this institution and there have been no changes lately in this respect.

I am taking up the matter of repairs, &c., in a separate letter.

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,

Sir,

I beg to submit the following report for the month of January 1937.

SCHOOLS

At Old Sun's there are three new staff— all are experienced and appear to be capable. The water supply is low and care must be taken in the use of water. The Bow River is very low and we have an idea that the well must be deepened to try to get a bigger flow unless the river raises and precipitation increases this year. All pupils are getting good attention. The hockey teams play excellent games with neighbouring teams and amongst themselves. This applies to both schools and the children are quite happy; no overnight leave to their homes is allowed during the winter. So far, serious colds and Flu have been avoided by following this rule.

Report for October.

Both schools were inspected. The Old Sun was inspected on two dates; first, when the District Sports Day was held there, at which the Indian children competed with whites from the schools in neighboring towns, and secondly, at night in company with Major Randle, of the Six Nations agency. All appeared to be running smoothly. Crowfoot school was inspected during the month and I was particularly interested in the splendid spirit of all the children in classroom and at play.

REPORT ON BLACKFOOT AGENCY FOR MONTH OF NOVEMBER 1938.

The principal of the Old Sun School broke a leg and was in the hospital for a short while but the school ran along as usual and there was nothing out of the ordinary transpired.

G.H. Gooderham
Indian agent.
At the Old Sun School the Principal was able again to take complete supervision and all branches of the work seemed to be going along quite smoothly. Very little manual training could be given because of lack of facilities and the instructor in this branch had the boys under his charge mostly on the care of stock. I was not altogether satisfied that the children looked as clean and tidy as they should, especially the young boys. It is all very well to allow boys to scuffle around and enjoy themselves and not be too dressed up to do so but there is a limit both ways. Neatness and tidiness is certainly one thing that Indian children must be taught.

G. H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.
Dear Sir:

I beg to submit herewith my report for the month of January 1939.

A regular inspection of the Old Sun School was not made, but the writer was there to see a hockey game and found all enthusiastic and apparently in good health. At this school, we are pleased to report that outdoor sports are encouraged. There are two excellent boys hockey teams and the Principal has also taken under his wing a hockey team comprised of graduates, who are playing in a provincial amateur league, and giving a very good account of themselves.

G. H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.
At the Old Sun School there has been a change in staff when the girls' Matron returned to Aklavik and was replaced by a matron who is a qualified nurse and comes from Sioux Lockout.

AGENT'S REPORT ON BLACKFOOT AGENCY FOR DECEMBER 1939.

SCHOOLS

Both schools were inspected and all the children were well and happy.

At the Crowfoot school fire escape doors were completed on the 14th. At both schools there were Christmas concerts when the parents loaded their children down with presents. It seems to be a case of "keeping up with the Jones'" and with the cooperation of the principals we hope in the future to stop this considerable waste of money on useless trinkets.

G. H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.
Gleichen, Alta., Mar. 6, 1940.

AGENT'S REPORT ON BLACKFOOT AGENCY FOR FEBRUARY.

SCHOOLS

Both schools were inspected and at the Old Sun's I felt that there should be some shake up in staff as it was evident that general conditions were not as good as could be expected. I took it up with the principal and he stated he was of the same mind and had already asked his commission for certain changes. This school is doing reasonably good work but there is certainly room for improvement. However, the children are happy, healthy and well fed.

For sometime now it has always been a pleasure to inspect the Crowfoot school. There is such an air of happy well organized industry everywhere in this institution. The class work, particularly in the intermediate class rooms, is well organized and well done. The other work, outside the class rooms, is certainly above the average. The children are very happy, they have a grand time and are just as enthusiastic about their work as they are about their play; they are unusually well fed and their sports are also very well organized. I must add that at both schools there are good hockey teams. A team composed of Old Sun School graduates is entered in the Junior Intermediate Provincial Playdowns, and at date of writing have not yet been beaten.

G. H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.
Gleichen, May 8th, 1940.

AGENT'S REPORT ON BLACKFOOT AGENCY FOR MONTH OF APRIL.

GENERAL XXX

SCHOOLS XXX

EXD XXXXXXXXX

Both schools were inspected and pupils were found to be in reasonably good health and cheerful—especially so at the Crowfoot school. Some changes should be made at the Old Sun School in the staff; the nurse is not efficient, nor is one of the Matrons. The principal also advises me that he proposes to strengthen his teaching staff by putting a more capable teacher in the junior room. I respectfully agree, as it is this room that the real ground work is done. One member of the staff, Mr. Bell, the farmer, has enlisted, and has been replaced by Mr. Toons, who has been at this school for some time and will carry on very well, I believe. Mr. Bell was an especially good farmer and brought the farm and the dairy herd to the highest point of efficiency and productivity in the history of this institution.

At the Crowfoot school the spring run-off cut a deep canal right through the middle of their farm, at the rear of the institution. This canal has been in existence for some years in draining off the water from north of the town of Qu'Appelle and the artesian wells in the town. The existing canal is dangerous and something must be done to prevent further erosion and it is now our duty to find out with whom the responsibility or fixing this rests.

At both institutions everything is ready to go ahead with seeding when conditions will allow.

G. H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.
Gleichen, April 4, 1940.

AGENT'S REPORT ON BLACKFOOT AGENCY FOR MARCH 1940.

SCHOOLS

The writer was on holidays the latter half of the month and did not inspect any of the schools. It is reported, however, that everything has progressed favorably.

At both schools, it has been the policy, in which this office concurred, to keep the names of pupils on the register until they were about 13, even when such pupils were not in residence. This policy permitted what might be called, has worked well, particularly with the boys. They have moved themselves back when they knew that they might be brought back to the school. It is now realized, of course, that the financial set-up does not allow for remuneration to the church schools for all children whom they may be able to enroll. One of the schools on this reserve has been in residence quite a number of pupils for whom they did not get the grant. We have had some assistance in financing and it must be said here that the standard of living and general care of pupils, even in this school was very much higher than it was in the years gone by.

Although the writer has never been in favor of the large boarding schools, I think it must be admitted that the churches do educate the child at less cost than if the Government paid all the costs of education, under the same conditions. We have also concluded that the cost of medical care could be materially reduced if more assistance could be given for new work in schools. I think this has been proven by the conditions existing on this reserve. After all, health and education are intertwined and one cannot be considered without the other.

As it is now the policy of the Department to discharge pupils at the age of 16, we feel it is in the best interests of the Indians to try to work out some scheme of control of those children who leave at that age.

G. H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.
Gleichen, July 9, 1940.

AGENT'S REPORT ON BLACKFOOT AGENCY FOR JUNE.

SCHOOLS

Both schools were inspected in the last week of the month when everyone was busy cleaning up for the year. At the Old Sun School the principal had practically all children in the garden and on the irrigated land, which I think was the very best way to employ them. The abstract teaching of the classroom doesn't get very good results with Indian children and I feel that there isn't enough realistic work given to them. The Old Sun farm and gardens are very good indeed. At Crowfoot School the junior room shows what a really good teacher can do; the Sister in charge has developed a bright class by realistic teaching. The pupils of this school have done some excellent handicraft, none better can be found anywhere. The farm crop looks very good, but the gardens are poor at this institution. Children appeared to be in good health and happy; particularly so because they were going on holidays very soon.

G.H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.
Glenchen, Oct. 7, 1940.

AGENT'S REPORT ON BLACKFOOT AGENCY FOR SEPTEMBER.

SCHOOLS

Children returned to schools on the first of the month and the Principals reported that nearly all came back quite promptly. Some of the larger boys were allowed out on harvest work and are still out. It has been difficult to get new pupils started but presumably they are now bringing results. There are less children in these schools than there have been for many years as children over sixteen have been discharged. The principal of the Old Sun School tried to get two of his "teenage pupils," who had completed grade eight, into the Glenchen High School, but the Board of Trustees would not accept them despite the fact that arrangements had been made to pay the fees. He brought it to the attention of the Department of Education, Edmonton, stating that in his opinion the Board of Trustees should have been prepared to accept these children as there was nothing in the act to state that they should refuse their admission. There was some correspondence about it but Mr. House had arranged a correspondence course, nothing further was done, but the writer brings it to your attention as he believes that there must be something in Mr. House's argument. Why should an Indian be refused admission to a school which has the accommodation, if the Indian can meet financial obligations and is physically fit?

The crops and gardens at both schools are encouraging and have been harvested. Although the writer wasn't in a position to make an inspection during the month he knows that the teaching staff of both schools have been greatly improved with the appointment of teachers who have had normal training and higher qualifications than those who filled a number of these positions in past years.

G. H. Groderham,
Indian Agent.
Gleichen, November 14th, 1940.

Dear Sir:

Herewith my report for the month of September 1941.

SCHOOLS:

Schools did not open until the 22nd and the writer did not make an inspection after that date. Pupils were apparently happy to return but the parents have been very slow in bringing in children who were entering for the first time. As usual, there was the unfortunate situation where there are mixed marriages and many disputes as to which school the child should attend. Our only interest is that the child of school age should go to school and we do not consider it our duty to either advise or dissuade the parent where the child must be placed. Very little vocational work has been started at either school as accommodation has not yet been provided. A temporary plant to supply necessary water at Crowfoot School has been set up. Dear Sir:

Herewith my report for the month of October, 1941;

SCHOOLS:

At the Old Sun School I found the classroom work well in hand under two very capable teachers. There is a good nurse on the staff and I was interested to note that most of the pupils had gained weight during the summer and that their weight charts indicated that the parents had looked after the health of their children. REPORT ON BLACKFOOT FOR MONTH OF JULY.

SCHOOLS

Inspections were made at both schools in company with the Inspector and visiting officers. Very necessary repairs had been arranged for but nothing has been done except some interior painting. At Crowfoot school the garden was badly damaged by hail which was confined to a very small area in and about the school; fortunately the grain crops were only slightly damaged. This school has a surplus of feed from last year and is now getting more from the Indians with still more of their own to harvest. At the Old Sun School, alfalfa was harvested and the garden as well as grain crops looked very good. This institution has lost a number of the staff, including the nurse, two women supervisors and the man in charge of vocational training. It is understood that all vacancies cannot be filled.

At Crewfoot School extensive repairs were made to the main building and to the water supply system. This school is now in better condition than it has been for many years. At both institutions the principals have been busy with their harvesting operations and despite a labor shortage have done surprisingly well and are harvesting excellent crops.

Dear Sir:

Both schools were inspected; Crowfoot school was in splendid order, three class rooms with qualified teacher, and a night watchman making hourly rounds, except for a few cases of colds all pupils were well and happy.

Threshing has been completed with good returns -1900 bushels wheat, 1800 bushels of barley and 5 to 6000 bushel of oats, besides a good quantity of green feed; unfortunately the yield from the garden was ruined by hail.

Old Sun School all running smoothly, but one senior teacher was temporary from the principal anticipated a difficulty in replacing her. A number of the children had light attacks of flu, nothing serious.

All crops have been harvested with a satisfactory yield, though the yield from the garden was not as big as hoped; very little vegetable, will have be purchased.

Both schools anticipated a shortage of staff and great difficulty in filling vacancies.

Your obedient servant,
G.H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.
Dear Sir:

An inspection was made of the Old Sun School and this was confined to barns, stock and the kitchen and basement of the school; all was operating smoothly though there was no surplus coal. Class rooms were not inspected; there is now only one teacher and she has taken to junior room half the day and senior the other half. The kitchen matron was leaving the end of the month, and so far as is known the Principal has been unable to replace her and had to reorganize his remaining staff. On the whole the children are doing well, though a few had colds.

Your obedient servant,

G.H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.
REPORT ON BLACKFOOT INDIAN AGENCY FOR MONTH OF DECEMBER, 1942.

SCHOOLS:
Both schools were inspected; I found everything going along smoothly despite a shortage in staff; the work and the instructions were well done. The children were well and happy. This is particularly true at the Crowfoot school where I attended an excellent concert.

At both schools the cattle and hogs are raised for home consumption and market; one school even had a surplus of cream for sale.

G.H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.
REPORT FOR THE MONTH OF FEBRUARY, 1943.

SCHOOLS.

The Old Sun school was given a thorough inspection, the children were happy though a few had light colds; the staff had been depleted again with the enlistment of a man, & the nurse assumed the position of a police matron in the city of Calgary. Despite this all work was proceeding in orderly manner; the principal takes the vocational training, at which he is very good; the remaining teacher takes Juniors in the forenoon and Seniors in the afternoon; and the matron looking after the infirmary as well as her other work. The diet was ample and varied and there was lots of milk butter fat; the meat ration was reduced. I was particularly gratified with the care given to stock; the farmer is a good stockman and has his milk herd in splendid condition. The boys do all the work and do it very well. This school will have a surplus of feed at the end of the winter. At present there is only one breeding sow here. The hog house is a mere shell and very small; as a result pigs can only be raised in warm weather.

No inspection was made at the Crowfoot School but all was running smoothly according to last reports.

G.H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.
REPORT ON BLACKFOOT INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF MARCH, 1943.

SCHOOLS:

Owing to the press of other work neither of the schools were inspected.

At the Old Sun School the second teacher has arrived and a young man has been employed to assist the principal with vocational training.

At the Crowfoot School the principal has taken full charge of all branches of the work and business of this institution. The health of the pupils at both school was good.

G.H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.
REPORT ON BLACKFOOT INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF MAY, 1943.

Schools;

Both Schools were inspected and condition found to be exceptionally good. There had been an epidemic of flu but all children look strong and happy; the diet had been changed owing to the difficulty in getting meat, more vegetables and other foods were supplied; Farm and garden work was well cared for and there was ample milk and eggs at both schools.

G.H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.
REPORT ON BLACKFOOT INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF JUNE, 1943.

Schools;

Both schools were visited and inspected and conditions found to be very good. Parents and pupils were told that they must return to school on the 1st of September and so far as is known there was no objections to that. All children are now on holidays.

G.H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.
REPORT ON BLACKFOOT INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF JULY, 1943.

Schools:

At the Crowfoot school, the principle and his staff were busy working erecting an excellent piggery. The crop on the school farm is fairly good. The Principle is going to find it very difficult to finance if he takes in more pupils than the grant allows. Costs are increasing as well as food prices and labor is hard to get, wages are higher.

At Old Sun School the haying was the order of the day; a good ton of alfalfa was secured and the crops and gardens were irrigated and looked very good. The Principle is having a terrible time getting labor and holding staff. A thorough inspection was made of the roof of the school and it is expected that the cost of making it weather proof will be considered. All pupils were on holidays.

G.H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.
REPORT ON BLACKFOOT INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH SEPTEMBER, 1943.

Schools:

Two or more inspections were made at each of the schools during the month. Most of the pupils returned at the opening date.

At the Crowfoot School there are now 102 pupils, equally divided, boys and girls. They appear to be in pretty good health and happy to be in school.

At the Old Suns School there are 90 pupils.

Both institutions have a good staff of teachers and work was proceeding in good order. Both have very good crops and have harvested them. There is ample garden stuff, milk and meat to meet the immediate requirements.

G.H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.
REPORT ON BLACKFOOT INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OCTOBER, 1943.

Schools;
Both schools were inspected. Pupils were healthy and happy and these institutions were running smoother than at almost any time in our experience. The diets were good though the milk supply could be increased. This, of course is seasonal and as cows freshen there will always be ample.

G.H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.
REPORT ON BLACKFOOT INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH NOVEMBER, 1943.

Schools;

Both schools were visited and inspected. The health of the pupils was good and the class room work appeared to be quite satisfactory. Little had been done in Manual training as the members of the staff, who are in charge, were otherwise employed. The boys, however, had been employed on good practical vocational work.

The large roof on the Old Sun School was renewed by a contractor, under the supervision of Mr. Nelson. Fine weather is the greatest assistance and it is believed that a very fine job was done. At this institution the water level in the wells dropped and steps were taken to stop all leaks and keep a steady flow into the water tanks. By the end of the month, this institution was getting sufficient water but there was certainly no surplus. The farmer at this school has an excellent herd of cattle; there is evidence of good care and supervision. The boys received good instructions in animal husbandry and care of poultry.

At the CROWFOOT SCHOOL, the raising of pigs is a large industry; a fine quality of bacon hog is being produced here. Since the Blackfeet are raising hogs it is a good thing that the youngsters are being taught how to look after them.

It requires a great deal more attention and experience to raise hogs of the right type than it does to raise horses and cattle; and this is one thing that must be instilled into the minds of these young Indians.

Both schools supply a splendid diet to their pupils and have a good supply of vegetables and meat.

G.H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.
REPORT ON BLOOD INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF JANUARY, 1944.

Schools:

Regular visits were made to the residential schools during the month, and were found functioning well, with all students at school.

The result of the T.B. Clinic, necessitated the discharge of two children from St. Mary's School and three from St. Paul's School, and their removal to the T.B. ward at the Indian Hospital. Observation cases in both schools were named in letters to the Principals along with instructions for their care; these instructions came from Inspector C.P. Schmidt.

The St. Paul's Indian School this month won the award for the best amount of their quota, in this case around 600%, in doing this the children purchased during December & January around $165.00 worth of stamps.

Anthony McMillan,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

REPORT ON BLACKFOOT INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OCTOBER, 1944.

Schools;

There were 197 pupils at the two schools when inspected this month; all were happily and looked well. Classroom work was progressive and at Crowfoot School typewriting is being taught to some seniors by the teacher who recently qualified.

All plants were operating satisfactorily and buildings in good state of repair. Everything was running smoothly.

REPORT ON BLACKFOOT AGENCY FOR MONTH OF NOVEMBER, 1944.

SCHOOLS

The Indians are better off than many of their white neighbors; they have well run boarding schools where there are teachers, good food and good clothes. Many white schools are closed because no teachers are available and even if the schools were open the children would travel miles each day to attend. Classroom work has been found to compare very favorably with white schools in equal grades and besides the class work, Indian children get vocational training that many whites can never get. The trend in neighboring white schools is to form large units with dormitories and vocational training added to the basic three R's. The trend is towards the Indian boarding school system rather than away from it. The Blackfoot see this now and are showing more appreciation of their schools. There is only one thing wrong. Not enough money is allowed for the operation; salaries are too low to attract the better qualified and more efficient. Withal, reasonably good work is being done, but what a gamble.

G.H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.
QUARTERLY REPORT ENDING MARCH, 1945, ON BLACKFOOT INDIAN AGENCY

Education:

There were 200 pupils attending the two residential Indian Schools and 3 attending the Gleichen High School.

The Mumps epidemic did not break up the routine very badly at the boarding schools; classroom work went on as usual and was much of the same calibre.

At the Crowfoot School, dormitory space was increased by moving the quarters of the senior matron of boys and girls into the hallway and very comfortable and well ventilated rooms were erected over the stairways at either end of the buildings. At this school, the girls are receiving training in typewriting and music as well as domestic and sewing; the boys are not so fortunate; they receive good training in care of stock but no manual training. The Principal is anxious to supply this when a competent instructor can be found.

Despite the fact that there are over 100 children in this school (30 over the grant) they are very comfortably housed and very well fed. The Principal and Sister Superior deserve all the credit.

The Old Suns School is also running smoothly; the Principal Rev. J.W. House, is a capable administrator. He secured the services of a qualified manual training instructor and the boys are now receiving regular training.

There is a need for trained carpenters and mechanics on this reserve and it is our hope and expectation that a few boys will graduate from year to year, who will make carpentry or allied trades their vocation after some apprenticeship.

The boys attending high School did very well this term. They proved one thing, that they can do well when made to apply themselves to this work.

The Old Suns School has a Cadet Company and good hockey teams. The Crowfoot School also has hockey teams.

G.H. Gooderham, Indian Agent.
QUARTERLY REPORT ENDING JUNE 30th, 1945, ON BLACKFOOT AGENCY

EDUCATION:

Attendance was good at the two boarding schools and very little time lost by sickness. German Measles and colds did keep some in bed for a couple of days.

The class room work wasn't so good at either school as in 1944-45. Changes in teaching staffs brought less qualified persons to this important work. The Indians are conscious of this, but during the war years they have made allowances. There were no pupils in either school who would pass into Grade IX. The three boys who attended Gleichen High School wrote Grade IX. The results are not out but the principal states they were capable of leading their class when they worked; we did our bit to keep them working and hope they made it.

At the Old Suns School, the training in carpentry, farming and care of stock is particularly good. Ex-pupils get employment and show the results of this. These schools should turn out some boys who could most of the repair work on the reserve. On the Blackfoot Reserve, there is enough carpentering and painting to keep two or three men employed. The generation of Indian carpenters is now past work; they were the product of industrial schools at the beginning of this century. We must produce more like them.

One could go on at length about the education of Indians. It will, I think, be conceded that the grant must be increased, the calibre of staffs raised and a definite contract made with the churches that run schools, before definite results can be expected or demanded.

G.H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.
Blackfoot Indian Agency
Gleichen, Alberta.

AGENT'S REPORT FOR THE QUARTER ENDING DECEMBER 31, 1945.

XX XX XX

Education: Two boys are attending Gleichen High School in Grade 10; they are doing alright.

There are 200 pupils at the two residential Boarding Schools. They are healthy and happy. Vocational training has been improved and the calibre of the instructors satisfactory.

Classroom work always appears to be lacking in something; possibly this is due to lack of interest by the pupil but it is so easy for a teacher to get in a rut and lack that spirit which the child needs so much to retain its interest and enthusiasm. Indian children love to sing and they are good singers. We need to practice a little more psychology to get nearer the desired results.

All children who were school age and physically fit at the beginning of the term are attending the schools.

At both institutions, the farms produced ample feed for stock. Good milch herds are retained while the flocks of fowl produced sufficient eggs. Some cattle and pigs are slaughtered for school consumption. The Crowfoot School has a splendid lot of pigs. The Old Suns School had a splendid garden on its irrigated farms.

Dear Sir:

In reply to yours of the 31st ult., I enclose herewith the petition which the Blackfoot Indians signed in connection with the building of a new school.

The petition was taken around the Reserve by the Rev. Mr. Gibney at the request of the Chiefs. Before he did so, he asked me if it was in order and I stated that I could see no objection. The Chiefs and some of the Indians who are Protestants approached me at the same time and stated that in their belief, the Members of the Band would be glad to ask the Department to loan sufficient money from Band Funds to erect the school, provided it could be built this year. The petition was completed and handed to me by Mr. Gibney on August 4th.

The Indians want a school and at that time (July) were afraid that the children might be sent to other schools. Even if a school could not be provided during the present school year, I am satisfied that the Indians are prepared to advance necessary funds to proceed with construction in time to allow occupancy in the fall of 1929.

It is hoped that Day schools can be started by October 1st at the latest. If the Indians keep their promise, the pupils of Old Sun's will continue school work as usual. Health conditions will be watched and the Church authorities have supplied considerable clothing from other points for the children of the poor parents who cannot purchase necessary clothing.

Your obedient servant

Dear Mr. Hoey:

The sudden death of Canon J. W. House has made necessary two changes in the Principalships of our schools.

At the meeting of our Committee last week Archdeacon H. G. Cook, who has been the Principal of our School at Moose Factory, was appointed Superintendent in the place of Canon Alderwood. There has thus been necessary a change in the Principalships at Gleichen and Moose Factory.

1. Gleichen. After careful study of the situation in Alberta it has seemed best to transfer the Rev. E.S. W. Cole from St. Cyrian's School at Brocket to succeed Canon House at Gleichen. Mr. Cole is 45 years of age. He served for five years during the war. In January of 1946, at our request, he was appointed by you as Principal of the School at Brocket. His service has been satisfactory. We would ask therefore for approval of his transfer to Gleichen.

2. Moose Factory. Mr. Herbert Taylor has been serving in this school as Assistant Principal since August last. During part of the time when Archdeacon Cook was away through illness he acted as Principal in his place. He is twenty-six years of age, married with two children. He served for six years in the Army first in the ranks and later as an officer and Adjutant of his Battalion. His service at Moose Factory has been very satisfactory. We would ask for his appointment as Principal of the School.

Yours sincerely,

LAD K.

In regard to the sum of $80,000.00, which was taken from the Blackfoot Band Fund to assist in the erection of the Old Sun Residential School on the Reserve in 1929/30, it is noted that the Council of the Band is inquiring as to when this will be paid and if same will be paid with interest.

This Band, by the surrender of a large portion of their reserve in 1911, has now the largest Band Fund, I believe, of any Band in Canada. At the same time, from that date the Band has paid for practically everything that was done for and on behalf of the Indians of the Band from this fund. Aside from the two schools, the Agency building and the house of the Superintendent and one clerk, all other buildings on the Reserve are the property of the Band. For many years there were expended from Band Funds, on behalf of the Band, for various services which included staff and medicalization, as well as programs of development, an annual amount of approximately $150,000.00.

During recent years the expenditures from the Fund have risen for the same services that they were formerly receiving until the necessary expenditure for the year 1948/49 is about $250,000.00. By their surrender agreement the Indians were prepared to pay the salaries of added staff to carry on the farming and ranching program, and this program was commenced in 1912. It is not necessary to elaborate on this, as we are all aware that the costs of farming have increased tremendously during the interim.

The services which these Indians were prepared to supply themselves have since been supplied to most other reserves from appropriated funds. In 1925 the Band erected a hospital, and from that date has paid all operating expenses, including the salaries of a resident doctor and staff. This was done voluntarily. They also paid for outside hospitalization, including stays in sanatoria over a period of years. Since 1925 they have seen the medical services on behalf of Indians gradually grow in extent and expense until today it is no doubt the most expensive service on behalf of the Indians. They are now having free hospitalization at the Cassell Hospital for tuberculosis patients, and all other medicalization and hospitalization is still charged to their account. They have noted, furthermore, that Bands of Indians similarly situated have received all these services at no cost to them, because they did not turn their land capital into a liquid capital. This has given them food for thought.
R. A. Hoey, Esq.

Feb. 12/48

The Blackfoot are very proud of their ability to pay their own way, but the cost has now become so great, it is wondered if it is fair to allow them to continue to do so.

This brings us back to the advance for the erection of the Residential school. The Indians will undoubtedly continue to press for payment as they must increase their capital and revenue to meet their obligations.

If the salaries of necessary staff could be paid from appropriation, a heavy load would be taken off the Band Funds. The existing condition is not a healthy one, nor does it appear to be entirely fair. Staff is employed without consulting the Indians who pay the salaries, and it is increasingly evident that the better educated Indians object vehemently to this. It is argued that if they have to pay for the staff, they should have some say as to who will be hired and the salary that will be paid.

Insofar as hospitalization and medicalization are concerned, the Band, through its Council, have indicated that they will meet this obligation, as they were the first to have started hospitalization in the country. Whether or not the resident doctor and nurses in the hospital can be called necessary staff is debatable. The Indians believe that a resident doctor is part of the necessary staff of an Indian Reserve, and that if other members of the staff are paid from appropriation, then the salary of the doctor should be paid.

The foregoing is brought to your attention, Mr. Hoey, because there is no desire on the part of anyone, I am sure, to willfully exploit this Band, but unwittingly there may be a tendency to do so, and now is the time to curb such a move.

G. H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report, dated 18th January, 1930, from the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, submitting that the main building of the old Sun Indian Residential School on the Blackfoot Indian Reserve, in the Province of Alberta, was destroyed by fire in June, 1928. The Blackfoot Indian Band, wishing to expedite replacement, petitioned the department to take from its funds whatever was necessary to proceed with a new building at an early date. For the current fiscal year, Parliament provided $40,000 towards the replacement.

As the amount required, however, is $120,000, the Minister recommends that authority be granted for an expenditure of $80,000 from the interest funds of the said Blackfoot Band, which now amount to $880,474.79, under section 93 of the Indian Act.

The minister states that it is proposed that this amount should be refunded to the band within the next two fiscal years in conformity with the department's policy that all cost of Indian education should be defrayed from public funds.

The Committee concur in the foregoing recommendation and submit the same for approval.

E. J. Lemire,
Clerk of the Privy Council.

The Honourable
The Supt. General of Indian Affairs.
Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Old Sun Indian Residential School.

In 1929 the Old Sun Residential School was under construction on the Blackfoot Indian Reserve and funds were not available to complete the project. Therefore the following resolution was passed by the Blackfoot Band:

"We, the undersigned, members of the Blackfeet Indian tribe, and living on the Blackfoot Reserve, Gleichen, Alberta, beg to approach the Department of Indian Affairs with the request that they take immediate steps to provide a fully equipped and modern building, constructed of brick and as fire-proof as possible, to replace the Old Sun Indian Residential School on this Reserve, which was recently destroyed by fire.

"We, further, beg to suggest that sufficient monies for this purpose be borrowed from our vested funds in order that no delay may take place in meeting the above emergency in an adequate manner."

As a result of this resolution, the attached Order-in-Council was passed.

The sum of $80,000.00 thus obtained was used for the completion of the Old Sun Residential School.

On different occasions during the last eighteen years we have included in the preliminary draft of our
estimates this sum of $80,000.00 but the item has always been deleted.

We are now advised by Mr. Gooderham that the Council of the Blackfoot Band is inquiring as to when this amount will be paid and also if interest will be allowed on it. Mr. Gooderham advises the Indians will undoubtedly continue to press for payment as they must increase their capital and revenue to meet added obligations from their Band Funds.

In again asking reconsideration of your decision in this matter I am influenced by the fear expressed by Mr. Gooderham that delay may cause the Blackfoot Band to accept the invitation of the Alberta Indian Association to appoint delegates to represent them in that Association. Should the Band decide to do so, the result would probably be that representations would be made to us and to the Members of Parliament for Calgary, with the result that when the matter is settled, no matter how voluntarily, the Association and its self-appointed publicity agents would claim credit for forcing the hand of the Government.

It appears to me that it would be preferable to settle this matter without waiting for any further representations from the Band or pressure from the Indian Association or persons whom the Association might influence to plead the Blackfoot cause.

Within the next week or so the question of management of Band Funds will be considered by the Parliamentary Committee inquiring into the Indian Act and I would like to have some provision for settlement of this matter made before being called upon to report on it.
In view of the above, I would strongly recommend that consideration be given to the inclusion of the following amounts in our next supplementary estimates:

(a) Return of funds borrowed from Blackfoot Band Trust Fund for construction of Old Sun Residential School ............ $80,000.00

(b) Interest on the above from January 29, 1930 (date of O.C.) to March 31, 1948, at 5% simple interest ............ $72,668.49

Total ....... $152,668.49

Old Sun Residential School:

Accommodation should be arranged for 120 pupils. Authorization for a pupilage of 120 should be obtained. Above that number, pupils should be day pupils, and an attempt should be made to increase the time spent on academic subjects and directed progressive vocational training. This school has a "chore" tradition.

The principal wishes to create a third classroom by "walking off" the auditorium. The basement dormitory would serve also as the auditorium and theatre. The only alternative is to build more classrooms—if we intend accommodating all who should attend.

The principal agrees to employ three teachers. He should have four, but there is no fourth room.

As at Crexford, there is a small house (about 35' x 25') donated by the tribe, and equipped for Manual Training. To lack of an instructor it is not in active use.

This school, in my opinion, is in a more difficult situation than some people realize. It had a bad year in farming activities. Hay failed. Six milk cows had to be sold. Water is served to the pupils more often than is milk. Meat, potatoes, and vegetables have to be bought. I doubt the adequacy of the Principal, the farmer, the implements, or the boys available to cope with the peculiar agricultural problems that this institution presents. Help is needed. Who will supply it? Or will this school be allowed to follow the ineffectual pattern that Blood (C.E.) presents?
Although, as stated above, water appears on the tables more often than milk, during my two-day visit there was a shortage of water for the wash-basins and toilets. An attempt is being made to correct this shortcoming.

Similarly, the Superintendent and Principal are anxious to adjust the boys' toilets to a state approximating the original installation. The removal of partitions, seats, and toilet paper, and the apparent lack of any attempt to keep the bowls clean, has resulted in a situation better imagined than described. Supervision of this department is the duty of a maiden lady.

I am grateful to be able to report that this school has recently inaugurated a cadre of prefects. Unfortunately, at the time of my visit three of the boy prefects were missing, and no responsible person had any certain knowledge of their whereabouts.

The teacher of the upper grades, supported by the Principal, hopes to include Grade Nine in the work of the classrooms next year. I told them that I considered that this project had little to commend it, but I agreed that they should state the case for your consideration. In turn, I warned them that, if they proceeded according to plan, the outcome would scarcely afford reason for all-round congratulation, but rather the opposite.

C.O.T. Clark
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL.

The undersigned has the honour to report,

THAT under authority of P.C. 207 of January 29, 1930, the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs was granted authority to expend eighty thousand dollars ($80,000.00) from the Interest Funds of the Blackfoot Indian Band in order to assist with the erection of the Old Sun Indian Residential School;

THAT in conformity with the Department's policy that all costs of Indian education should be defrayed from public funds, P.C. 207 of January 29, 1930 provided that the above amount should be refunded to the Band within the following two fiscal years. This latter provision of the Order in Council was not put into effect and consequently the amount borrowed from the Band Funds has not yet been refunded;

THAT the interest on eighty thousand dollars ($80,000.00) from January 29, 1930 to March 31, 1943, at five per-cent simple interest amounts to seventy six thousand, six hundred and sixty eight dollars and forty nine cents ($76,668.49). The rate of interest just stated is the same as the Government allows on credit balances in the Indian Trust Fund.

At the present time, therefore, a sum of one hundred and fifty two thousand, six hundred and sixty eight dollars and forty nine cents ($152,668.49) is required in order to reimburse the Interest Funds of the said Blackfoot Band.

The amount just mentioned was included in our supplementary Appropriation, 1943-49, and it is recommended that authority be given for the payment of this amount to the Interest Funds of the Blackfoot Band.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.

Dear Dr. Keenleyside:

This will refer to your Minister's recommendation of August 21, 1948, for authority to reimburse the interest fund of the Blackfoot Band of Indians with the sum of $152,668.49, being the principle borrowed with accrued interest from January 29, 1930 to March 31, 1948.

While the Order in Council, which authorized this loan from the Interest Funds of this Band of Indians, provided that the loan was to be repaid within two years, it seems that no action has been taken until the current fiscal year towards meeting this provision of the Order in Council. Under the circumstances, it would be appreciated if you would submit for the information of the Board, detailed explanations for not repaying this loan within the period specified in the Order in Council, and thus allowing interest to accumulate to the substantial amount of $72,668.49.

From a review of the above Order in Council the only explanation which seems to have been advanced in support of the loan was that the Indian Band had requested the Department to take from its funds whatever was necessary to proceed with the building required at an early date. The Band's request was apparently granted in view of the fact that Parliament provided only $40,000.00 for this purpose, whereas an expenditure of $120,000.00 was required. However, as it has not been the policy of the Government to make loans from Indian Band Funds, the question has come up as to whether it was not considered feasible at the time to request Parliament to provide additional sums for this purpose. It would be appreciated, therefore, if you could review for the information of the Board the circumstances which led to the necessity of making this loan.

Dear Mr. Bryce:

I am in receipt of your letter of September 11th, with reference to the Minister's recommendation of August 21st, 1948, for authority to reimburse the interest fund of the Blackfoot Band of Indians to the sum of $152,668.49.

Owing to the economic conditions existing at the time the loan should have been repaid as provided by P.C. 207 of January 29th, 1930, it was found impossible to provide the necessary funds. The matter has been considered on several occasions since that time but owing to other urgent demands, previous Ministers apparently felt that the matter could be allowed to stand.

In the last year, the Council of the Blackfoot Band has strongly urged that their funds be reimbursed to the extent requested and provision for the repayment was made in our appropriation for the fiscal year 1948-49.

It is noted that the question of interest is mentioned in your communication. Permit me to point out that interest at the rate of five per cent (5%) is allowed at the end of March each year on the "Revenue (Interest) Account" of each Band and, consequently, if we had repaid the loan at the time provided by P.C. 207,
the amount would have been placed in the "Revenue (Interest) Account" and the Band would have been allowed five per cent (5%) interest each year. Consequently, the amount paid in interest would have been much larger than the amount of interest that we are now recommending be allowed.

It is regretted that the file does not disclose the reasons for the departure made from established policy in this case, and we can only conclude that the Government of the day had not set up sufficient funds for the purpose and took advantage of the offer of the Indians to get the work under way.

It may interest you to note the following entry which appeared in our estimates for Indian Education for the fiscal year 1929-30:

"Old Sun, Alta. (C.E.).

The main building at the Old Sun Indian Residential School was destroyed by fire in June, 1928. The Indian Band in Council, wishing to expedite the erection of a new building, has offered to advance from its funds whatever is necessary to effect an early replacement. It is proposed to commence the erection of the new building in the early summer, and, when parliamentary appropriation for the purpose is expended, the funds of the Band will be used to complete the work. A year from now, Parliament will be requested to provide sufficient funds to reimburse the Indian Band. The appropriation required this year - approximately one-half of the cost of the new building - is ........................................ $40,000."

Yours sincerely,

Deputy Minister.

Re: Reimbursement to Interest Fund of Blackfoot Band of Indians - Legality of making payment from Vote 772, "Indian Education".

I acknowledge your letter of October 8, 1948, in which you ask whether an amount appropriated by Vote 772 of the Appropriation Act, No. 4, 1947-48, may be paid into the Revenue (Interest) Account of the Blackfoot Band of Indians. I realize that its preparation will involve a great deal of work on your part and on the part of all your assistant editors, printers, etc. However, this work is well worth while and you will all gain valuable experience from it. I am therefore looking forward with interest to the arrival of the first copy here of your new venture.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

During the days to come, this our first year book, will bring back to mind many pleasant memories.

OUR PRINCIPAL'S INDIAN NAME

On November 11, 1948, when the Indians were gathered together for a memorial service, our Principal was given the Indian name of "Blackfoot". English Indians scan walkers came there on walks across the sky to keep us warm and to light the world. Mr. Cole walked among his Indian brothers to teach us to be Christians. The Senior pupils and some of the Staff were there at the time Rev. Cole was given his Blackfoot name.

Grade 6

REMEMBRANCE DAY - 1948

On November 11, 1948, the Blackfoot Indians held their first Remembrance service. They joined together in the Crewe Hall in memory of the boys who served in the second world war. They remembered especially Gordon Yellowsky, who lost his life in the Frontenac Mines. A wreath was placed on the grave of Gordon. All the men marched in as the drums rolled. Mrs. Old Woman carried the flag. Then there were some speeches and we sat praying and were silent for two minutes. Even the little children were quiet.

Grade 6

GIRLS' AUXILIARY

The word "auxiliary" means helping and that is what we try to do as members of the Girl's Auxiliary. We not only realize that we are making someone happy but we are training ourselves to be able to help others expecting no reward for doing so. We also learn to be better and take pride in our work.

Most of us are interested to know what others are doing so Miss Hicks, our leader, reads to us and tells us about the many different branches of the G.A.

Earlier in the fall a circle was a fantastic show for which every girl had to dress up. Miss Hicks borrowed a photograph and we were told to make costumes for the roles she had in mind.

We are always happy to have Miss Stearns, the superintendent of the G.A., come to visit us. She teaches us many songs that are new to us and we really have a great time when she is here.

Last week we met here on Friday 10th and we realized over ninety dollars. The girls contributed towards buying the proceeds towards altar furnishings.

We have had a very fruitful year and have learned a great deal. I am sure all the graduates are sorry to leave. We only hope that next year the Girl's Auxiliary will be a success again.

Beatrice Crowfoot

A. Loving Heavenly Father, giver of life and light and power; give us hearts that love Thee, i.e. to love Thee, i.e. to serve Thee. Great God, we send all members of our Girls' Branches may be joyful messengers of Thy love wherever Thou dost call us. Bless Thy national schools so that they may be a blessing to all. May all the children, we with them, may be used to bring many souls to Thee. Teach us to do the things that please Thee, and show us where and how we best may serve and glorify Thee; through Jesus Christ our Lord. Amen.
As Girl Guides, we have many little duties to do in and out of school. We are proud to be part of the Order of Canada. Miss Vincennes is our Governor, Miss Captain Beatrice Crowfoot is our Company Leader. We have five different patrols, each with a leader and second.

Four times a month we have our meetings in the dining room or sometimes we take field trips. During the early weeks of February and March we built a fire outside and made s'mores.

On 7th March, the Principal took us to a Guide rally at Celery. The Guides, Boy Scouts, Brownies, Cubs and Rangers from Celery were there. As we went through the hall, the Guides there were told to stand at attention. Then we took part in the Grand march. We stood at attention for two hours, at least it seemed that long. Later we were introduced to other Guides, where we started for home. Although the wind Mr Cole could hardly see to drive but we got home alright.

On 9th June, we were enrolled as Guides by the Bishop of the Calgary Diocese. We received our pins. The ceremony was held in front of the school. The wind was so strong our hats kept blowing off.

Now even though none of us are graduating this year we will still be members of the Girl Guides.

Delma Mayfield.

CONFIRMATION

On Easter Sunday, the Bishop of Calgary came down to confirm thirty-eight of our boys and girls.

The girls wore white dresses with lace around the bottom. They looked very lovely.

After the service our parents had lunch with us in the children's dining room. Our parents were very proud of us that night. The Bishop regretted that he could not stay to visit with us.

HALLOWEEN

Cecelia Y.O.W.

On Halloween we had our first big party of the year. It was a grand one too. There were quite a number of us who masqueraded. There were two funny horses. The girls' horse had a chuck wagon behind it. Betty was dressed as a native of India. There were two girls who really made us laugh. They were dressed as ghosts and they danced and pranced all over the place. The main prizes went to these people.

Our parents, Mr. and Mrs. Pugh and Linda, Mrs. Oliver, Dr. and Mrs. Hoepel joined in our fun. We played games and danced. Sonny and Henry were in costume and did the children dance for us. After lunch we went up to our dormitories and quickly donned off to sleep.

CHRISTMAS

On the Sunday before we went home for our Christmas holidays we put on our first White Gift Service. The senior pupils each made or bought a gift for the service. All the children brought some money in their envelopes from every country of Europe. We were very proud when we took our gifts to the front of the Chapel. We had our first concert this year but we had a little concert on the eve before we went home, the grade nine had a "surprise party" for the Stars. They invited Mr. and Mrs. Oliver, Mr. and Mrs. Evans, Dr. and Mrs. Hoepel, Mr. and Mrs. Marshall, Miss Watkins, Cpl. and Mrs. Yates (continued on next page)

Mr. Yates Sr., and all the senior boys and girls. As the guests entered the dining room, they were given paper hats. There was a short program and Miss Claus introduced the seniors. Then the seniors presented us to the sitting room where they were served by the grade nine girls. Mr. Pugh and Dr. Hoepel stayed and visited with the children until they were all seated for lunch. The tables were set festively with candles on each one. On the head table was our Christmas cake.

The following day we had our concert again for our parents and the juniors. The little ones sang for us as well. Yes, and Santa found time to pay us another visit.

VALENTINE'S DAY

On Valentine's Day the Girl Guides put on a party. Miss Decker and our Governors helped us get things together. We sent invitations to the Stars. Jennifer Thomas and Arthur Whitelock were chosen Queen and King of Hearts and they gave out the valentines. We played several games. Miss White played the piano for us and was an expert pianist.

We had lunch and then danced, played more games and enjoyed ourselves thoroughly. Then the boys sang, "Good-night Ladies" and we didn't dance and went to bed.

WINTER BOATS

In April we had our first winter boat of the year. We had our bonfire on the girl's playground. It was such a big one that the police thought the school was on fire.

We sat on benches around the fire and sang songs. The next thing we knew, we were running in. It was showering. Presently we came out again. Then we had our "hot dogs" and apples. The juniors went to bed early.

Delma, Dorothy, and Marjorie sang "The Old Rugged Cross". Everyone was so quiet as they sang this beautiful old song.

Then the boys played the drums and sang while we danced around the bonfire. Mr. Cole really was funny! Before we went in we sang "For He's a Jolly Good Fellow" to Mr. Cole. We always appreciate that Mr. Cole and the Staff do for us.

Cecelia Yellow Old Woman.
SPORTS

The rink was not ready in time for skating last winter but we managed to get down to see a few fast hockey games in Glencoe.

As soon as the snow had gone the boys and girls were "itchy" to play soft ball. We had some good games after tea and after supper.

On May 28th, the children all walked down to participate in a field day with other schools at Glencoe, Glengarry and Dwyer. As usual Mr. G. hired two trucks to bring us home for dinner and take us back for the afternoon. Teddy Yellowly brought us back again at four o'clock. Several of the pupils won prizes. Tim Sherron, David Yellowly and Rachel Langbein won Honors. Tim was outstanding in the Pole-vaulting event.

On June 4th Tim, David and Rachel went down to compete with some other schools. They again won some ribbons.

Lila Healey
We enjoy the shows that we have every Tuesday evening. The ones we liked best this year were "Tom Brown's School Days", "Let There Be Music", and "Breaking the Ice". We always enjoy shows with that wonderful singer Bobby Breen. Everyone will be looking forward to the shows again in September.

Miss DeGroot taught the older girls some shell craft on Wednesday nights. The sets they made are lovely.

Our school paper was well on the way to being published but because of circumstances that could not be helped, it was never completed. However, it will be published regularly next term.

The tuck-shop was opened in February but has been closed for the last few weeks. Selina and Patty were in charge. There were apples, chocolate bars, candy, peanuts and soda biscuits for sale. Everyone lined up in the hall and waited for their turn to be served. We are glad to have a canteen in school and we hope it will open again in September.

We had a lovely surprise when we came back to school after the Easter holidays. Mr. Cole had bought two radios for the boys' and girls' playgrounds. We enjoy them so much that we often would rather stay in and listen than go out to play - but we must have our fresh air!

Beatrice, Evelyn, and Lila brought the smallest boys and girls who couldn't speak English their Sunday School lessons. We are sure they must be very good teachers.

Mr. Hugh comes around at least once a month to see our school. He always has a big smile for us. We are no longer shy of him. One time he went into the kitchen just as Miss Twigg was taking some burnt cookies out of the oven.

Grades five and six.
CHIEF CROWFOOT

The warm sun was shining brightly on Sunday afternoon, 26th September, 1948, when we, one hundred and twenty-one pupils of Old Sun, started to walk to the Crowfoot Hall. This day was the occasion of the unveiling of a monument by Mr. Crowfoot, a great grandson of Chief Crowfoot. Those taking part in the ceremony were seated on a long platform including our late Head Chief, President of Long Island University, Dr. Robert B. Gordon, M.D., of Medicine Hill. Both Trude and Ileana and Senator Gertshaw told us something of the history of Chief Crowfoot. It seems the old Chief had been very powerful in war, but the white man came and took his land away when he signed the Treaty in 1877 he never went to fight again and was a good man of peace from that day until his death in 1890. The Indians were drawn in our native homes and the whites came closely here, a very good advice and told us we should try to live a life as good as Chief Crowfoot did after he became a Christian.

Beatrice and Christine Crowfoot, Valerie Beaton and Norman Mohan were present at the unveiling. After the Ceremonies they went over to the home of Superintendent and Mrs. Pugh's to assist in serving tea to the people from Calgary and the Indian Children who came from the nearby reserve, Rocky View, the Towne Brothers. We came back after the Ceremony and saw a lot of people looking over our school, they even watched us serve supper.

Delma Harfield

The monument reads:

"Great Chief of the Blackfoot Confederacy. Born about 1830, died 25th April 1890. Fearless in war, but lover of Peace, he promoted unity among the Tribes of the Plains and friendship with the White Man. He surrendered his Elected Chiefs and the Great Title to their tribal lands in 1877, began to adopt a sedentary life, and remained loyal during the North-West Rebellion in 1885. His nobility of character, his gift of oratory and his wisdom in council gained for him the title, 'The Father of His People.'"

The R.C.M.P. invited us down to see some films that they showed in the Gleichen Community Hall. The main picture was "Scarlet and Gold" - all about the life of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. There was also a reel on the strange animals of Australia. We all enjoyed the evening very much.

We have enjoyed many good BROADCASTS on the radio that Miss Willson gave us. The two we enjoyed most were "Western Getaways" and "Listening Musicians".

The boys have been down to the river two or three times for a SWIM. There is nothing like a "duck in the water to cool one off."

The girls haven't been swimming but we have had some nice long walks. One very hot Sunday afternoon, we walked down to the Stampede grounds. We were so hot and weary, we didn't know how we were ever going to be back. But Mr. Holmby's truck came along sight unseen and we were glad when he killed his horse and gave us all a ride home! We surely did appreciate that ride. It was the first time we were cool that day.

Mrs. YATES has kindly given much of her time in training the choir and playing the organ on Sundays for our Chapel Services. We all appreciate this very much.

MR. COLE AND CANON COCK went down to Oklahoma to attend a conference. We hope they enjoyed themselves and aren't too tired after their trip.

MR. COLE SR. and MR. CHENELLS made a really good job of our chapel house when they were visiting us. We hope they enjoyed their visits. We always like to see Mr. CHENELLS for she always has a smile for us.

We were very lucky this year that we had so little SICKNESS in our school. Of course we had some cases of the "flue" but compared to other places we can't complain.

When Miss WATKINS' foot gets better she is going to nurse again in our hospital. We hope her coming back men as she likes us. DR. HIOPEL is always a welcome visitor even though he does "poke" us with a needle sometimes.
The following is an article that was written in the "Indian Voice," a newspaper of the Indians of B.C.

**Canadian Indian Girls Train in New Zealand**

Two Canadian Indian girls have recently made an important step in the world of Indian welfare when they journeyed to take up their studies in maternity nursing in far off New Zealand. Miss Norah Scowen from Saskatchewan and Miss Dorcas Oberton from Alberta are now students at St. Helen's Hospital, Wellington, N.Z., where they will undergo special two years' course in their chosen field of nursing.

The girls have already had a year's training in their chosen profession at the Canadian Mothercraft Hospital at Toronto.

It is interesting to know that the curriculum used at St. Helen's Hospital embraces the methods of the late Sir Truby King which he developed at parliament schools as far advanced in their medical fields as they were the private factor in New Zealand at the top of the list for better babies and low mortality for years.

The two Canadian girls will be in direct contact with the most progressive Native race in the world. The Maori race of New Zealand has shown the world that they are able to hold their own in this world today. These natives have not only members of Parliament; they also have their own entire members in many of the leading professions in that sister Dominion.

The most encouraging angle of the whole picture regarding our progressive-minded girls is their proved determination to work among their own people when they return to Canada.
